reviewText:
Ah, DOOM! This franchise brings back so many memories.

This BFG Edition comes with the original DOOM and DOOM II. I hear a lot of people say that's it's better to get the original DOOM 3 because it's more mod friendly, and get the Doom Classic Complete because it comes with Final DOOM and Master Levels of DOOM II.

Well I already own DOOM 3. I believe it was the first game i got back in the day when I built my first rig and dove into PC gaming. I remember that awesome feeling. The graphics were just beautiful. There was all this talk about how you needed a $3,000- $4,000 PC to run the game on Ultra I was so giddy with my new PC being able to run DOOM 3 in at least High settings. I never got the expansions, so this edition takes care of that. I am looking forward to finally playing them. The biggest difference from the original DOOM 3 and this re-release is the fact that the flashlight is gone. The flashlight added a tad to the game, you chose to light up the room and be vulnerable or walk in the dark but properly equipped. After a while the whole thing was just annoying and you just wanted to ductape the damn flashlight to your shotgun. In DOOM 3 BFG, the flashlight is now integrated into your armor. So far, i really don't miss the flashlight.

Right now I've mostly played the Original DOOM. I love that game. I never played it on PC, I owned it on the SEGA 32x. At the time I really had no idea how watered down the 32x version was. I almost don't recognize the stages because they are not as dull as they were on the 32x. It had been like a decade since i played the original DOOM and for the most part, i still remember a lot of the stages and secret areas. I'm having a blast reliving this game. I got this whole game for $5 on Amazon. I already feel like i got my money's worth.

I never played DOOM II, so i am definitely looking forward to that.

For $5 I think this was a great pickup for me. I can live with not having the complete edition of the classic DOOM games, and as far as DOOM 3, i never really used mods with it. Maybe I'll get the classic complete on the side later. Only thing that puts me off a bit is that i hear that DOOM Classic Complete runs on DOS Box. The games that are included on this version, don't run off DOS Box.

The only real con about this game (Maybe others aren't having this issue) is the fact that i cannot minimize the game. The game acts like it's minimized, your windows taskbar comes up on the bottom, but the game is on top of your desktop, so you can't pull anything up, the game is always on top.

reviewText:
It's a neat idea to have a remastered version of 2004's Doom 3, which also contains RoE and classic Doom games, but i don't think it's that good as i thought. You know why? Because of the changes to Doom 3 and RoE and classic Doom games:

1. Game being brighter. I know a lot of people thought that original Doom 3 was TOO dark, but making it brighter reduces the atmosphere that this game has. Even with lowest brightness setup, the game is a little bit brighter than max brightness in the original.
2. Mounted flashlight - probably THE MAIN reason why a lot of people prefer this version over the original. Makes sence for console versions (PS3/XBox360), but PC - not so much. I like that vulnerability situation when you hold a flashlight in the original game and there's an enemy in your face. In this version: Enemy in front of you in the dark room; flashlight on; shotgun to the face with flashlight on. Also the flashlight is limited, unlike the original 2004 game.
3. Ammo. The game quite literally feeds you with an ammo. In Level 4 of Doom 3 campaign i ended up with full shotgun and machine gun ammo. Even on Veteran, it's easy with all that ammo. I think it makes sence for console versions to feed you with an ammo, but for PC - not at all.
4. Level changes in RoE are just stupid in my opinion: Waste Tunnels have been changed by removing the gas in the tunnels and the helmet in this kind of an airlock, so you don't have to kill Hazard zombies to get their oxygen tanks, well you need to kill everyone you see, but you get the idea. Entire section in Hell, where you need to use an Artifact to puch out a bunch of Mancubi, Hellknights and Imps, is completely gone, The Maledict fight is easier because 1. He doesn't spawns Lost Souls, and 2. The rocks (or meteorites or whatever the hell they are) do less damage.
5. If you think it's enough of changes? No, because the changes to classic Doom games are even worse: Wolfenstein levels after Map 15 are just naked"

This package is absolutely outstanding.

10/10

reviewText: You get all three Doom games in one package.  If you've never played Doom, you owe it to yourself to play this.  If you've never played Doom 3, be prepared for a wild ride.  The first two games started the first-person-shooter genre, yet are still fun; but Doom 3 is the most disturbing, scary, and twisted game I have ever played.  After more than ten years since its release, I still haven't seen another game that forces such a sense of urgency and fear upon the player, as this game does, and it does it perfectly.  Turn the lights off, put the headphones on, and be ready to kill, die, and run while sh*tting your pants.

reviewText: DOOM 3: BFG Edition is a great DOOM Collection!  You get DOOM 3 and DOOM 3: Resurrection of Evil with better graphics, a flashlight that you can have on while holding a gun, there is a lot more ammo, and they feel smoother than the originals. You also get the new expansion DOOM 3: Lost Mission, which I really love! Plus you get The Ultimate DOOM and DOOM II (and they don't run through DOSBox!). DOOM II doesn't come with The Master Levels for DOOM II, but it does come with DOOM II: No Rest for the Living (which was only available on the XBOX 360 version before). So overall, I Like this DOOM 3 more than the original, I love DOOM 3: Lost Mission, but I prefer the original DOOM 3: Resurrection of Evil. This D3:RoE has changed a couple things and took out a couple areas, I don't know why but that is why I prefer the original version. But I still LOVE DOOM 3: BFG Edition and would recommend it!\n10/10

reviewText:
This is quite a nice game. It's terrible as a sequel to the original Doom games, but it -is- a good game! Please, let me explain. The original Doom and it's sequel, Doom II, are fast-paced shooters in which you strafe about wildly shooting at hordes of demons on a Mars base, with no real plot to speak of, and it's just raw FUN. Doom 3, on the other hand, really tries to...honestly, I'm not sure what the heck they were trying to do. Here's what we got, though: a shooter that cares more about jump scares and being dark; effectively a survival horror game in space with tons of health and ammo drops.

The game itself is good, despite being a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ization of the original games' tone, because the shooting and some of the creepy tone work well enough to make for an exciting time. That said, the shadows really, really, really suck. They're graphically nice, but this game is DARK. On the bright side (see what I did there?), Doom 3 BFG Edition fixes one very big problem: the flashlight. In the original release of Doom 3, the flashlight is held in your hand like a gun...meaning for you to see well, you can't have a gun out. Guess what's in the dark? That's right, bunches of enemies. This is one of the biggest gripes people had with the game, myself included. People modded in a flashlight that worked while you had your gun out, and in Doom 3 BFG Edition, the developers have automatically made the flashlight/gun combo an automatic feature! The game is now eerily dark, but you do have a flashlight to make it not suck" to use the technical jargon.

To quickly interject
date: the fact that Doom 3 BFG Edition includes Doom (1993) and Doom II is wonderful! I played through both and had a magnificent time. The games were just as good now as when I played them way back when
recommended: and I'm very rarely a nostalgia type of gamer. That said
hoursPlayed: people who didn't play them originally might not like them!\n\nIf you want a game that feels like the original two Doom games

reviewText:
DOOM

Родоначальница FPS. Только дурак незнает что такое DOOM.

В DOOM3: BFG Edition можно увидеть DOOM, DOOM II и собственно DOOM 3
И вот поэтому я советую именно его, тут оптимизировано все. Если вы купите отдельно 1,2 часть игры то она будет запускать ее через DOS Box, и собственно придется привыкать к управлению на стрелочках и стрельбе на кнопке Ctrl.
Можно включить и мышку но опять же придется привыкать. А в этой сборке старый добрый DOOM играется с дичайшим удовольствием.

по поводу DOOM 3, у кого стоит скриншот на F12 то меняйте его на(допустим) Num+ ибо есть баг при котором достижение отключаются при  тисканье F12, и собственно в дальнейшем вы останетесь без достижений.

Этот Bundle должен пройти каждый. Каждый должен познать страх, ненависть и убить всех исчадий ада. ;)

10/10 безоговорочно.

reviewText:
If you have never played Doom, this collection is a great way to introduce you to the franchise. With the seminal Ultimate Doom, Doom 2, and an idTech 5 port of Doom 3 to start with, this package also contains a couple of expansion packs that have never been released before. Namely, No Rest for the Living for Doom 2 and The Lost Mission for Doom 3. In the months following its release, ZDoom and its derived ports have been adapted to be compatible with this version of the Doom and Doom 2 data files, so if you're into modding, you should no longer have an issue running ZDoom mods with this package's version of Doom 1 & 2.

If there is one thing that really disappointed me about this edition of the game, it's that it does not include other commercial iWADs that were included in previous classic Doom collections and compilations. Namely, there's no Plutonia, TNT, Master Levels for Doom or even D!Zone levels included. It would also have been nice if this was finally the legitimate way to acquire Hell 2 Pay or Perdition's Gate.

Considering who this is marketed to though, I can't really blame them too much for it. If you've never heard of Doom, I would recommend it. However, die-hard doom fans can very much afford to skip on this, or failing that, wait for a sale if they HAVE to get No Rest for the Living or The Lost Mission.

reviewText:
I played a ton of Doom 3 (non Steam edition), so I don't really need much time of this version to get my impressions.

I've heard a ton of racket on the internet about how terrible this port is, which has prevented me from buying it. It went down to $5 in the sale, and since it came with Doom I and II, I figured it was worth at least a try. The main argument against this version is that, hypothetically, Doom 3 with the expansion and a few modifications installed surpasses this version. I have to say - getting Doom 3 working, widescreen, on Windows 7, with mods, is quite the pain in the ♥♥♥, and the benefit is really not that much.

The BFG addition adds a different flashlight mechanci from the original, and on top of that, the game is brighter in general. The added brightness really makes the game flow a lot better. The flashlight is now attached to your suit, but can't stay on forever, needing a bit of time to recharge. The overall effect is that the game is a bit less tense, but it just plays way better overall. The game is stuck in ultra settings, with no way to adjust the quality downward, and there's a terrible motion blur setting that is fortunately easy to disable. There's also the previously console exclusive Lost Missions, which are a couple of extra bonus levels.

I think this is the definitive Doom collection. If you want to play the Doom games, this is a good place to go. You can have them all under one roof, functional, without having to play with a ton of INI files to get them working well on your modern machine.

reviewText: Just a fantastic game all around,and probably one of my personal favorite FPS!!Doom 3: BFG Edition is cool because it contains the first two doom games plus the Resurrection of Evil expansion that adds 8 new levels to the game.The Resurrection of evil expansion really gives you a lot of extra game time(Almost as much as the base game)Plus it's got achievements.So you really are getting a  lot of bang for your buck! I loved the first two Dooms, and had planned on purchasing them until i noticed they were included in this pack.That makes this def worth picking up.If you can get it on a sale then hey even better!The plot is pretty decent,and the voice acting is for the most part well done.You play as  a transfer to the Union Aerospace Corporation located on Mars.The UAC has been doing research on artifacts that were recently discovered in an archeological dig.Dr. Betruger the director of research at the Union Aerospace Corporation research facility on Mars has used these artifacts to open a doorway to hell.Turning everyone into evil possesed asshats ,and unleashing legions of hells demons.Soon after your arrival at the UAC things start to go south ,and it's up to you to fight the evil and save humanity. Now I've seen a lot of people complaining about a few of  the graphical changes ,and honestly i really didn't notice that much of a change.That being said It has been many years since I've played this so i guess it wouldn't matter much unless you recently played or have a great memory!Then there's those who say it's unmoddable....well i hate going around downloading crap ,and messing with files so with me it's fine!Also that this version is super easy with health and ammo laying around everywhere.Well there is but there was in the original if i recall.Also there's difficulty settings so just play it on hard if you find the game a little to easy.As far as atmosphere is concerned this game has tons of it!It's visually appealing and it's opressive,dark,creepy ,and definitely leaves you feeling like your alone in space fighting legions of demons.Nice level design,and the bosses are all great!Do yourself a favor,and pick it up already!!!

reviewText: Great game, has a nice little story and loads of content, coming with DOOM 3, the resurrection of evil DLC DOOM 1 and 2 and a new campiagn, The lost mission. The multiplayer may not be very popular but personaly I enjoy it and I play it quite a lot. The lighting is great. It can be quite scary, it makes an exellent horror game with spooky sound effects, turns and hallways. There will be demons hiding behind the next corner or behind a door making you feel like there will allways be enemys and loads of them. On the down side the multiplayer can be laggy if your not hosting, and it will be common for you to get high ping, like in the hundreds (if your not hosting). But all together it makes a great game and worth your money depending on what type of game you like. This comes with loads of content so it should keep you busy for a while. (7.6)

reviewText: It adds everything to the game that was needed so that it is much more enjoyable now. Plus it comes with the most ground breaking fps's of all time, Doom and Doom 2, but in imo should've also came with Final Doom because it has by far the best made and most challenging levels of all Doom games. The only two things I can think of about this game that suck are when you get hit and the shotgun. When you take dmg your view jerks wildly making your view all cockeyed and off and you have to re-adjust. It's bad when you are getting shot but really bad when you get hit in melee. Also the shotgun is the most useless weapon ever put in a video game: you can be two feet away from a basic zombie and your shot won't kill it because the weapon spread is so incredibly wild. I can stand nearly against a wall and fire and the bullet marks cover about a 4ft radius. There have even been user made mods to correct it because it's so bad. Use them because otherwise the shotgun is useless. But the rest of the weapons in the game are solid and satisfying when you fire them.\nSome people dislike this because it is nothing like the original Doom's. I would give it about a 7.5/10 compared to the original Doom games being a 10/10. Hopefully the new Doom game will recapture the magic that this game left out. Still though, the guns and monsters are faithful to Doom and that is what makes this game a fun playthrough.\nThis game is still a good classic. Pick it up for a lot of fun and a lot of scare moments that will have you sh-tting your pants.

reviewText:
Firstly, if you have played DOOM 3 before, really liked it and you're wondering whether it would be worth getting the BFG edition or not: Get it yesterday already, marine!  You get DOOM 3, yes, but also more of the same asskicking gameplay in two awesome mission packs (Ressurection Of Evil & Lost Mission) and, on top of that, DOOM 1 and DOOM 2 are added on just for old time's sake so you can relive where first-person shooting really began.
If you're brand new to DOOM and you're a first-person shooter kind of gamer, well, are you in for a treat! - DOOM 3 is said to be one of the best FPS games ever, developed by the people who actually popularized the genre: id Software.

The story in short:
It is 2145 and humans, under the auspices of the Union Aerospace Corporation (UAC), have established a research facility on Mars.  Employees are mostly engineers, scientists or soldiers.  Research is being done in the fields of biology, space exploration, teleportation and weapons development.  Furthermore, exciting evidence has been found of previous inhabitants: an alien civilization that was destroyed by a vicious and seemingly unstoppable enemy.  Incredible times.
However, a growing unease has filtered through UAC personnel.  Rumours are abound of strange things happening,like unexplained voices and otherworldly creatures roaming the facility, sometimes resulting in accidents or even loss of life.  In addition, the facility, under Dr. Malcolm Betruger, is running an ever-increasing tab on the corporation's resources and Earth has sent a representative to investigate.  It turns out that Betruger, through his work in teleportation, has opened a portal to another dimension and in so doing has enabled hostile creatures to come through to Mars.  In reality, these creatures are demons and the place they come from is ... hell.  They are the same malignant creatures that destroyed the ancient Martian civilization.
You play a marine, freshly imported from Earth and dumped into the chaos, on a crusade to stop the evil from invading the Mars facility and, ultimately, Earth.  You have a range of weapons to your disposal, but you will also have to gain information and access to other parts of the facility to complete your task.  You do this by collecting PDA's from personnel, dead and alive, scattered throughout the base.  Since the main portal is situated in hell itself, you will have to travel there (following in Betruger's footsteps) and retrieve a powerful artifact called the Soul Cube which can be used to defeat the enemy's mightiest warrior (as well as assist in the downfall of many other along the way) and close the portal.

The game can be divided into three large sections: 1) the Mars facility, 2) Hell and 3) the Mars facility revisited, although in the latter part the Mars base and hell ultimately becomes indistinguishable from each other.  Once in possession of the Soul Cube (you bring it back with you from hell), demon attacks become more vicious and your strategy in using the artifact to your advantage becomes key.

Slight changes have been made to the original DOOM 3 (for example, certain triggers and enemies have been taken out and some of your weapons sound a bit different), but you may not even notice it.  The biggest change maybe is how the flashlight works: it is not handheld anymore but a fixed item, so you can use it while you're actually shooting (a definite plus), like in QUAKE 4.  However, the flashlight dies after about 30 seconds and then needs to recharge (in a few seconds) before it can be used again.  Whether this is a good or bad thing probably depends on individual opinion.  Of course, the benefit would be that you don't ever need to manually turn it off, maybe saving you some seconds to concentrate on enemies.

Mission Pack 1: Ressurection Of Evil (RoE)
You play as a different marine who finds a new artifact on Mars but in the process opens another gateway to hell.  An old enemy, Malcolm Betruger, revels in the prospect of newly invading the world.  Three bosses (hunters") are released that you will later have to defeat one by one.  You get instructions from Dr. Elizabeth McNeil to destroy the artifact
date: which (of course) must be done in hell.  So
recommended: once again your character travels through the complex on Mars untill you find a portal to hell.  Enough said
hoursPlayed: no more clues.\nSome new weapons are introduced: a "grabber gun" and Sarge's shotgun (find the cabinet code first
voteText: though).  The grabber gun may not seem like much

votesHelpful: boxes
votesTotal: drums and stones) and to catch fire balls mid-air and throw them back at enemies.  It can be used to directly kill small enemies and pick up items that are out of reach.  Sarge's double-barrelled shotgun is a valuable tool at close range
votesFunny: boasting more punch than the game's regular shotgun.  It fires two cartridges at once

running for cover or making sure to have some obstacle between you and your foe when you're not shooting.

Mission Pack 2: Lost Mission
You play as the only surviving member of Bravo team (remember them from the original Doom 3?) who got wiped out while on a mission - it all starts with a replay of the cut scene from the original game
column20: showing the demise of the team by the hand of some maggots/imps (it is the same incident that damages a cooling rod in the reactor

column24: who informs you of a problem: it so happens that there still exists a working teleporter in "the other dimension" (hell) that could assist the enemy's ultimate goal: invading Earth.  So
column25: once more into the breach you go.  You find your way to hell and reach the portal
column27: until you face off with a copy of an old enemy from the original game - the Guardian (no seekers this time) - to achieve your goal.\nIn Lost Mission (as in RoE) you get to travel through other
column29:
the place is quite expansive).  Your journey even includes a short boat trip on molten lava.
There are no new artifacts (also no Soul Cube).  Sarge's sawed-off double-barreled shotgun as well as the grabber gun from RoE make a return.

All in all

reviewText:
As you might have guessed, Doom 3 BFG Edition is a package that includes Doom 1, 2 and 3 (including RoE and all new expansion for Doom 3 and No Rest For The Living for Doom 2). Sadly no Final Doom or Master Levels, but essentially this was designed specifically for the console players. But since they released it also for the PC, so should you buy the original games or this?

Doom 3:
All of the changes that have been made is a mod for the original game. Widescreen support? Mod. Flashlight strapped to gun? Mod. HD Graphics? There's a mod that makes it look better than this re-release. Seriously. They have also made everything more bright, which many say, including me, that it ruins part of the scariness of the original. Also the Lost Mission isn't that good, it's not really worth your time. In fact, the only thing that I can say is better than the original is that the loading times are a bit better. (also they removed the ability to open console so that's cool)

Classic Doom:
Well, you have your classic Doom 1 and 2. The changes they have made are interesting, they have censored some of the graphics in some sprites and textures, they have REMOVED CHEATS I repeat REMOVED CHEATS. I don't understand why they would remove cheats, I suspect since they initially were making Doom 3: BFG Edition for the console players but decided to put it on the PC. Also there is NO MULTIPLAYER I repeat NO MULTIPLAYER even though in the interviews for this game they clamed that Doom 1 and 2 would have multiplayer. Why? Who knows. Maybe they just didn't want to bother, I have no idea. Also some people claim this to be important but THEY HAVE LOWERED THE DIFFICULTY IN NIGHTMARE. Aka Nightmare is allot more easy now. They have made some other small little changes, but other than these major things, the game is still pretty fun.

Conclusion: If you want to play Doom 3, don't get this. If you get the Doom 3 Pack on steam it's allot cheaper. Plus it supports a huge amount of mods, while this doesn't. If you want to play Doom 1 and 2, don't get this. Get the original games, then once you bought them don't play them in steam. Extract the wad files and install a source port (ex. ZDoom) and then play away in whatever resolution your monitor is in!

But, if you are looking for a Doom 1, 2 and 3 pack... Well... Technically it is cheaper, but the wad files you get with this I heard didn't work with source ports for some odd reason and there still are no mods for Doom 3 so I would recommend the original.

TL;DR This isn't worth the money. But I'm rating it up since it's Doom.

reviewText: What this edition really gives you is DOOM, DOOM II and DOOM 3 in one package.  Start the game, and you select which you want to play from the main menu, so it’s all very neat and tidy. But apart from that, really, there seems little point in this edition. The changes id made are rather trivial. They made DOOM 3 scenes a little lighter, but less scary in the process.  Lets be honest, do we really care that we can now see the miles and miles of bland pipes that make up all the DOOM 3 backgrounds? They would have done better changing the sounds, which are rather bland. But anyway, is it worth it? If you already have the games, then no. There aren’t enough changes to even justify a sale price! But if you don’t own any one of the three, then yes, buy it! Wait till it’s on sale though, because it certainly isn’t worth the price id released it at.

reviewText:
Doom 3 BFG edition nicely wraps up the full DooM game series in a nice little bundle. However, when I first bought it, I really just wanted Doom 3.

The reason for this is in the old Doom 3, you were able to create custom maps and load up mods for the game to spice it up after you get tired of the campaign. I mean, the missions are almost all dark cooridors with enemies that ambush you at every turn. Carmack himself stated he wanted to make the next Doom game scary, and so he sacrificed the gameplay for this. Yeah, the horror game gimmick is there, but it wears off fast. After ten missions of it, you expect having closets full of Zombies open after walking into a room where all of the lights go out because you touched an armor vest lying on a table. The reason why there was a map editor there at all was probably to encourage players to make their own levels if they were dissatisfied with the unchanging gameplay of the missions.

The BFG edition comes with Doom and Doom 2, which have extra missions you can play, but no multiplayer. The only game that comes with BFG edition is Doom 3, and I was a little disappointed with it for the reasons mentioned above. Despite that, the game is easier to play with the flashlight attachment to your weapons instead of needing to take it out to see what you are doing. Shadows in the new version are nicer, and there is a lost mission campaign to go along with the main campaign and the Ressurection of Evil addition.

I recommend this game to players who mostly use Steam, or if you don't know how to map or mod. But if you are like me who would rather make my own custom maps, or have fun with fan made modifications and addons, I would rather just get the original Doom 3 game.

reviewText:
Pro's:
- It's Doom 3. :D
- 3 Doom classics in one, including all episodes/expansions/DLC. No MS-DOS emulator ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t since D1-2 are played within D3 and can be played on the fly with a controller. Good move.
- New slick UI that does justice to this HD remake.
- Xbox controller support with on-screen button prompt.
- Steam achievements.
- Widescreen support.
- Revived Multiplayer.

Con's:
- No more flashlight weapon/item. ♥♥♥♥ YOU, YOU CASUAL GENERATION-COD ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Now, instead of changing weapons to your flashlight, you can keep your flashlight on with your guns, which kills all the horror factor. There's also no option whatsoever to change it back to the old way. Shame on you, whoever changed that.

- No more ADS zoom in. In the old D3, you could Right-click to zoom in. Not anymore. Completely absent from keybinding configs. Not a big problem, but still a cut feature for no reason(graphic engine update problems?).

- Some graphic's art have been redone most likely due to copyright stuff with Bethesda owning ID Software and all. 1st change that I noticed was the Medickpacks. In all 3 Dooms. Not a big problem here either, but old timers like me notice these things.

All in all, aside from these 3 con's, paying 5$ for a game that I already owned for an HD" update was worth it."

reviewText:
Most people writing these reviews, like me, don't have a billion hours in the bfg editions but we do have a billion hours in original doom 3 cds, and the older games as well. Doom 3 BFG edition is great for original fans of the doom 3 game/original dooms, but don't have the original disks to install (or floppy drives), and also want a little extra 'lost mission' campaign to throw in. This is also great for people who have never played doom 3 before.

The graphical enhancements to the doom 3 game annoy me a little (too bright now), but the enhancements of the original games make them much more playable. It's hard to see when we're so used to modern shooters. There are a lot of sweet mods (brutal doom for example) out there for the original doom games too, so players can enjoy the most recent doom games, and download some sweet mods as well.

This is definitely not a doom 3.5, to be perfectly honest. I believe that everyone else will probably agree with that as well. This is, however, a good all in one package with a cool (but short) extra new campaign thrown in. Some of us doom fans may have never owned doom 1 and doom 2 (plus the expansions), so it's nice to finally have all of those in an easy to reach steam title. The modding community (still alive today) for original doom and doom 2 adds a lot of value, in my opinion.

reviewText:
A nice collection of all Doom games wrapped up in one big package, sadly Doom 3 has some strange issues with stuttering and micro stuttering that i can't for the life of me fix.
Majority of the time Doom 3 runs at an amazing  buttery smooth 60 FPS but randomly after playing for a while i start experiencing stuttering and micro stutters untill i exit the game and relaunch it.
I'm not experiencing this kind of frequent stuttering in any other games and it's most certainly not related to PC hardware overheating since playing Doom 3 bearly heats up my CPU and GPU to 60c.
Even thought i had problems with the odd stuttering, I would usully get a fair amount of fun (about an hour or two) before the game would start experiencing this problem so I'd just simply quit and continue later on stutter free (for a while)

I'd say it's worth picking up during a nice sale IF you want to have all your Doom games under the same hood and IF you're not to keen on moding and just want an official Doom 3 version that has better support for modern OSs and hardware but I'd suggest buying Doom 3(2004 version) seperatly instead, during a sale and  preferably use some of those amazing graphic mods the community made for Doom 3 that blows the Enhanced" BFG version out of the water when it comes to graphical upgrades."

reviewText:
YES!
* The definitive DOOM games in a single bundle, mostly updated and ran as a single executable.
* PC version for No Rest for the Living (previously an Xbox (?) exclusive)
* DOOM 3 has improved graphics
* Armor lighting for DOOM 3 and expansions. No more panic-switching from flashlight!

NO!
* In a single executable, but switching between games could get tideous due to awkward interface.
* No Final DOOM
* DOOM 3/RoE gameplay is still stale
* No flashlight means no more flashlights run (but there's still the fists...)
* No Steam multiplayer on Ultimate DOOM/DOOM II
* No... Steam... multiplayer... on... Ultimate... DOOM... and... DOOM... II.

VERDICT:
=================================
RECOMMENDED, for: People who wants to delve themselves into DOOM, this is a great start to their collection. Or if you really, really, REALLY need to play The Lost Mission/No Rest for the Living.

NOT RECOMMENDED, for: People who already owned the games and can live without playing above expansions. Not recommended for modders, as well. Keep your zDoom/PrBoom/zDaemon handy.

OVERALL:
The cons really drive the game down. If you'd REALLY want a definitive edition, search for retail copies instead.
NOT RECOMMENDED

reviewText:
Simply put, this version is REALLY inferior to the original Doom 3. Downgraded graphics, slower weapons, stupid little features nobody needs and small little changes that are completely unnecessary. It feels like it's a console port now.
Oh and if you're thinking of modding the game, forget it. The files are neatly locked away and all mod support has been dropped.
Even the newly added Lost Mission campaign wasn't that impressive and many places of the maps were taken straight from the original Doom 3 campaign, but altered slightly.

reviewText: If you liked Doom 3, you'll like Doom 3 BFG edition. It includes Doom 1 and Doom 2, and if I'm not completely mistaken, all 3 are gamepad-compatible, so if you like using a gamepad or want to try the gamepad experience on doom 1 and 2, it is there for you to try. Loads of achievements and many are actually quite fun to complete, like Doomed Collector, where you need to find all of the PDAs in the Doom 3 campaign. Multiplayer is included, but at time of writing, the playercount is sparse. Setting up a match is easier than pie and takes not even minutes before you're jumpin' and jukin' and shooting your friends. I recommend this game to any enthusiast of the doom franchise, and any FPS gamers looking for a deal, it's hard to beat 3 doom games in one package.

reviewText:
The classic that tried to reboot a classic franchise. Some say it was a success, others a failure.
Regardless, it developed a cult following.

DOOM 3: BIG ♥♥♥♥ING GUN EDITION is the same game you enjoy from 2004, except with a few tweaks.

This game has always been a Western take on the Eastern Survival Horror" genre. It being Western-developed at the time meant more action oriented than what you were used to in a "Survival Horror" like
recommended: Resident Evil.\n\nWhen this game was originally developed they tried to separate it from the rest of the franchise by making it more visceral and scary. This edition still retains all of the same atmosphere and tension you remember
hoursPlayed: but they revamped the gameplay to make it like they actually wanted it the first time around: like Doom I and II. The game has more ammo drops and the gun locations have been somewhat changed making them a little easier to find. The textures have all been redone and upgraded
voteText: as well as the lighting. This is another spot that makes it different from it's initial release. Upon comparison you will notice the original 2004 was noticeably darker. That being said
helpfulPercent: they didn't have as great of an engine to show off back then
votesHelpful: either. The AI have been upgraded to be more responsive and ferocious as well.\n\nThis game comes filled with extra content. Not only does it come with DOOM 3

votesFunny: an all new expasion pack - DOOM 3: The Lost Mission
commentsCount: as well as the original DOOM I and II!\n\nThis is the definitive collection of DOOM
column16: I highly recommend it.\n\n10/10"

reviewText:
What can be said?  It's Doom.  Through and through, it's an ID Software Doom game.  Over-the-top represenation of the UAC and what Hell looks like, right down to the name of the monsters.  A word to any AAA developers, this is how you're supposed to make a very immersive FPS with scary elements.  Yes, there are jump-scares, but a lot of the atmosphere is just as scary as well (the sounds are absolutely amazing).

My only grip with the game is the gun order is not the same as the original Doom.  The original Doom was:

1 - Fist/Chainsaw
2 - Pistol
3 - Shotgun/Double-Barrel Shotgun
4 - Chaingun
5 - Rocket Launcher
6 - Plasma Rifle
7 - BFG 9000

I guess they were out-of-order since a few new weapons were introduced (hand-held grenades is one of them).  Regardless of that small gripe, this game is totally worth every penny.  A total steal when on sale.  So turn down the lights, throw on some headphones, crank up the volume and prepare to enjoy the Doom universe through and through.

reviewText:
Full Retail Price (Full Ripoff Price [For Certain PC Users Who Have Played The Original Game]): $29.99 (Actually The Price Is $32.43 If You Account for Tax)

Breaking Down Its Worth
___________________________________________________________________________________
$05.00 - (The Ultimate DOOM V2.1) + $04.50 (DOOM II: Hell on Earth V2.1) + $0.50 (DOOM II: No Rest for The Living [This Is The Only Addition To DOOM II That Makes The BFG Edition of DOOM 3 Worth Anything]) = $11.00

$16.43 (DOOM 3) + $06.00 (DOOM 3: Resurrection of Evil) + $00.00 (DOOM 3: The Lost Mission [This Is One of The Additions To DOOM 3 That Makes The BFG Edition of DOOM 3 Not Worth Anything]) = $22.43

$22.43 + $11.00 + $00.50 (The So Called New Features and Gameplay Improvements Plus The Limited Functionality and The No Plug In Support Included In The BFG Edition of DOOM 3 [3D Vision Is The Other Addition That Makes The BFG Edition of DOOM 3 Worth Anything) = $32.43
___________________________________________________________________________________

If you are going to buy DOOM 3: BFG Edition just because you want to play The Ultimate DOOM & DOOM II: Hell on Earth, then beware of the gameplay and graphical bugs that are in these releases and so if you just want to play The Ultimate DOOM & DOOM II: Hell on Earth, then i would suggest you buy The Doom Classic Complete on Steam rather than DOOM 3: BFG Edition.
*********************************************************************************************************************
This is one of the reasons why i do not think that DOOM 3: BFG Edition is worth the money because of these issues.
*********************************************************************************************************************
The autosave function in DOOM 3: BFG Edition sucks but the loading screens are much faster in DOOM 3: BFG Edition than they were in The original release of DOOM 3.
*********************************************************************************************************************
I do not care at all for the flashlight in DOOM 3: BFG Edition.
*********************************************************************************************************************
I do not care at all for the fact that they give you almost infinite ammo for every single gun in the single player part of this release of DOOM 3.
*********************************************************************************************************************
I most definitely do not care at all for the settings menu (Except for Support for High Definition Video Display Resolutions even though you can get that in UQE DOOM 3 and for That Reason Just Buy DOOM 3 and Just Use UQE DOOM 3, 3D Monitor + Compatible Glasses like for instance the Oculus Rift and a Framerate Cap) in this release of DOOM 3.
*********************************************************************************************************************
One of the only reasons why i bought DOOM 3: BFG Edition was because i wanted DOOM II: No Rest for The Living & DOOM 3 BFG Edition: The Lost Mission and the other only reason was so i could compare these releases with the original releases and by the way The Lost Mission is terrible.
*********************************************************************************************************************
I hate the fact that they censored The Wolfenstein-Commander Keen Tribute Levels from DOOM II: Hell on Earth in The Version of  DOOM II: Hell on Earth That Is Included In DOOM 3: BFG Edition.

reviewText: This version has better widescreen support, slightly better textures, and the ability to use your flashlight when you have a gun out. In other words it's nothing mods haven't done for the original game.. except that there is no mod support for these games that I can tell.\nAs far as the original doom/doom 2 games are concerned, don't play them on bfg edition. They really stripped down the options on this port, which means you can't set the resolution it runs at, making everything look incredibly jaggy, and there's not even a option to set your screen size that I can tell, forcing you to always have the status bar at the bottom. Best to plug the doom/doom2 .wad files into a source port like gzdoom, boom, zdoom, zandronum, anything beats whatever they used to run the games.

reviewText:
So this game is another id/Bethesda duo game. I'm gonna try and keep this short because I feel kind of embarassed when I write super duper long reviews.

Let me start off by saying I ♥♥♥♥ing love Doom. I do my best to share it with and introduce it to my friends because I want other people to discover this amazing series. Let me tell you a story about Doom 3, a true story.

Doom 3 did not tickle Scaramouche in the pickle department. No, sir. He wanted it very bad, but when he saw the reviews he was very easily turned off. The game did not seem close enough to older Doom games and when you have a gap like the massive gaping wound between Doom 2 and Doom 3 there has to be some connection, and here everything seemed awfully different.

Years later, Scaramouche actually bought this game during a summer sale - the Doom 3 BFG edition, not the standard. At this time all Mouche had was a laptop from 2008 but he figured that would be enough to run a game that came out around that time, especially with utilities like HiAlgoSwitch and whatnot. To his dismay, however... the game did not run at all.

Doom 3 and Doom 3: BFG Edition will only (ONLY!) run on computers with graphics cards that support OpenGL. While this does promise some decent graphics this is pretty uncool for people like Scaramouche.

Well finally Scaramouche got a desktop computer with much better specs, installed Doom 3: BFG Edition, and ran it.

It was nothing like the Doom 3 that Scaramouche had dreaded. This game was a different beast. Doom 3 standard seemed more like it would fit in with more generic modern horror games but Doom 3 BFG Edition was different. It had all of the spooky scariness of modern horror gaming and the spooky scariness of older horror gaming - Like old Doom. Scaramouche was very pleased and proceeded to play through it all as fast as he could as he went about comparing the two versions. The better flashlight and the tweaked balance were both great in his opinion. He was compelled to finish the game, and a few months later, he finally got around to recommending it.

Okay so... during our little story here we already talked about some stuff I liked about this game and honestly that's all I liked about it and it was enough for me to give it a solid rating. The old Doom feeling, the new updating lighting and graphics, the flashlight change (In Doom 3 you can't use a weapon while you have it out but in BFG you can) and the slight changes to balance all work in BFG's favor.

HOWEVER COMMA

... This game... brings a massive change in style to the Doom franchise. The enemies look oh so EXTREMELY different from the classic Doom games. They all have a more demonic look but... it... the enemy design didn't feel like Doom. It wasn't all cartoonish and badass, it was just... real-♥♥♥.

For example, I spent all game looking for Barons of Hell/Hell Knights and didn't see any - until I realized that I had, when I looked through the Doom wiki for stats on the Baron of Hell in Doom 2, ironically. They look SOOO different. They aren't big red guys with super cool giant horns wearing khakis. They're huge, buff Doom 3 Imps. And yeah they were supposed to be like huge, buff Doom Imps in Doom 1 and Doom 2, but they didn't just look like strong imps, they looked like Barons of Hell.

You saw it out of the corner of your eye and thought Oh god
date: now he's gonna shoot green ♥♥♥♥ at me right?" but you don't in Doom 3
recommended: you see it out of the corner of your eye and think "Ah okay just an imp
hoursPlayed:
I'll dodge that ♥♥♥♥ while I kill this Revenant because it's more important" and he ♥♥♥♥s your ♥♥♥♥.

And that's not all the change in look for all of the monsters does. The harder difficulties are recommended for Doom veterans so I was like "Well I've beaten Doom on Nightmare a couple times this shouldn't be too bad" but I got rekt on like the just barely over normal difficulty because I didn't know what the ♥♥♥♥ the enemies were gonna do because they LOOKED DIFFERENT BUT DID THE SAME DANGEROUS THING.

Also

reviewText:
Whew. Finally finished Doom, Doom II, and Doom 3, with all their expansions. Doom and Doom II were nostalgia trips, since I had played those a ton back in the 90's. They're still a lot of fun and there's so many levels with so many secrets.

Doom 3's original campaign is still one of my favorite solo FPS games. Highly recommend playing it with quality headphones because the audio in that game is top notch. The graphics still look all right considering its age.

The Lost Missions extra missions for Doom 3 were fairly challenging on Veteran, but not super hard. They have some good sequences though that made them worth playing.

Overall, highly recommend playing through the Doom 3 content at the very least. You can never have too much BFG.

reviewText:
Who's a man and a half?! Not this game.

It is a console port which not only adds unmoddable version of Doom 1 and 2, which you can obtain easily, but a version of Doom 3 which isn't moddable either, and is also set to a lower standard than the highest settings on Doom 3.

No changes have been made to Doom 3 whatsoever, save for a flashlight addition which is not even technically needed, as it added tension in a game that relied on jump scares, which, with the manual flashlight, made it all the more terrifying and frustrating as you made up situations in your head to stress over, as you picked between the two in a desperate attempt to feel safe, one way or the other, for there was no choosing both.

Rather that, you have the option of simply having both in this variant of Doom 3, which completely takes fear away and reveals the direction that Doom 3 had, which is nothing but throwing jump scares at the player's face as the game screams out, Are you scared yet?"
date: completely negating the effects on the mind that it once held.\n\nYou would do better to simply get a disc of the original Doom 3

reviewText: Doom 3 BFG Edition is a great game, but it does have some stability issues which are the resons why I would not recommend it.\nYou are getting a great deal with this package. Just $20 and you get an improved version of Doom 3 with two expension packs as well as Doom 1 and 2. Doom 3 keeps the same horror jump scare feel although it is more action based now since the flash light is now a shoulder light and there is more ammo then you can use. Now for the bad: it crashes. A lot. About every 20 minutes it will suddently stop working. It shouldn't be my hardware. I am running an a10 5750m APU with the 8970m GPU which runs this game at FULL settings with AA. It might be issues with Windows 8.1. So if you have Windows 7 or can handle the constent crashing then go out and get this game, but for the rest I say pass.

reviewText:
Where to start? There is no reason why anyone should get this version. The multiplayer setting of Doom 3 BFG is so absurd that I have to assume the devs decided to make the worst ♥♥♥♥ing game ever. I'll try to keep the list of horrors to a minimum:

1. No dedicated servers: in other words, you can only play with local people or else the lag will make you want to kill everyone in sight. Seriously, the game pairs you up with ANYONE. Regardless of the area in the world you are. Average ping here is about 250.

2. Absolute lack of multiplayer settings: WOOP. There is pretty much only 3D settings. As in no option for your in-game name (uses your steam name), team switches, votes...

3. Microphones are always on. Why in the ♥♥♥♥ would this be even CONSIDERED AS A GOOD THING?

4. Volume controls: What I mean here is that if you happen to want to play with your music playing, THE VOLUMES WILL KEEP GOING UP AND DOWN. WHAT THE ♥♥♥♥.

I think that's enough for the game. The only redeamable feature of this bundle is the original Doom and the revisited campaign of Doom3.

reviewText:
If you like Doom - DON'T BUY THIS BFG EDITION !!! JUST DON'T!

The BFG Edition includes:
- Doom 1 and Doom 2 playable fom the startscreen of the game.
- Doom 3 Console Edition which is less creepy and brighter than the original.
- Doom 3 Resurection of Evil (The Addon)
- Lost Mission (7 or 8 new SinglePlayer maps)
- A few Achievments for Doom 1, 2 and 3 + Multiplayer

The first thing i notice during playing the first chapter of Doom 3 is that everything is brighter and the textures don't look as good as they are in my memories. Also a shotgun mod I used years ago diden't work so I did a research on the BFG edition. The BFG edition is a port of the Xbox and PS edition of Doom 3. They portet the game to a newer engine that is also used in the game RAGE. I guess that's why the models are not as good as the 2004 PC edition, thats why everything is brighter ergo less creepy and thats why it's maybe not possible to mod the game after all.

That means no Hi-Def Texturepacks or any other graphic booster mod will work. The source code of the BFG edition was released but that don't change the fact that the beautifull graphic mods won't work at all.

So if you really like DOOM, buy the original PC edition and the Addon + the Doom 1 and 2 pack and you get a creepy game, modable that it looks like modern games and the classic DOOM levels PLUS you safe yourself some money!


About Doom 3 itself:
----------------------------------------
In the year 2094 or so supplies on earth runns out and humanity is trying to convert moon sand or in this case mars sand into water and fuel. They build a large station on mars with research facilities, fuel and water generators and so.

The crew somehow begin to act crazy and some rumors are all over the station, so you, a marine, came along to find some guy that is missing and the game begins.

It's like a merge of Half Life, Deadspace and SystemShock 2. At the end you carrie more than 9 weapons. the PDA system allows you to read e-mails or listen to audio-logs of many PDA's you (need to) find. Many of them contain information to open key-coded doors or lockers. The flashlight is your best friend since the station is falling apart. The enemy spawn system is a bit oldsql but with the dark levels and the near invisible enemies, it's creepy like Deadspace.

The story is pretty solid and reminds a bit of Half Life 1. So you start with no gun at a normal" day of work and it turns all into a big action loaded horror game. There are also noticeable Doom 1 elements in Doom 3. For example the fireball throwing enemie and the marine-zombies.

If you like horror generes
date: if you liked doom and if you are willing to download some extra texture packs
recommended: this is classic egoshooter game for you that brings really fun and can easely be moded to look like actual shooters. but DON'T buy the BFG edition like I did ;-)"

reviewText:
Warning: THis Version is NOT moddable!

Also:
- Cutscenes are unskippable.
- there is NO Editor!
- sound-design is very, very bad!
Everything sounds like an old kitchen-radio.

- The weapons, especially the shotgun sound like a plastic-gun. (the most iconic doom-gun, the Shotgun ! sounds so poorly recorded that it's a shame!).
- Killed enemies dissapear (!)
- Less gore than in Doom 1 & 2.
- It's too dark. I know it wants to create a spooky" and  dark atmosphere. But imho it fails and can't deliver much more then cheap Jumpscares (and hides many well build and textured assets in the world)
- less enemies than the predecessors
- much slower gameplay than the first two games!

I personally wouldn't recommend the BFG-Edition and would rather say: Go buy doom 1 & 2 instead
date: install the Brutal Doom-mod and have the fun of your lifetime (especially with some of the enhanced and remixed soundtracks like DoomMetal!)"

reviewText: I know that this game sounds good, I mean really, who wouldnt want all three dooms and their expansion packs in one game? But upon later inspection, or purchase, you will notice the flaws in the DooM 3 BFG. DooM 3 BFG is alot less compatible then just DooM 3. It will likely hate your graphics card, I tried this on 3 DIFFERENT COMPUTERS, I had problems with them all. If you are looking to mod doom 1 & 2 I would not recommend this, the wads have been censored and modified. As for doom 3, just buy the classic DooM 3. Trust me, it will probably WORK. The only way i could get DooM 3 BFG to work was only on one of the three computers i tried it on. I got it to work, but i have to enter multiplayer every single time i start the game, before going to the singleplayer/campaign, or it just crashes; Speaking of the multiplayer, that's dead too. You might as well get the originals seperately. They at least work the way originally intended and are moddable.

reviewText: The sound mixer is all wrong. Ambience is far too high, the already weak weapon and sound effects are -far- too low and every noise is kept on one central slider. You have no control over individual sounds. Basically, the sounds are broken and there's no way to fix it. Virtually none of the changes made were for the better and most are unnecessary to begin with. Also the classic Dooms are cencored and missing levels. All aspects of the Doom series covered in this package are only worsened by it. There is nothing difinitive about this version.

reviewText: I do like the Doom franchise but they didn't give support for those of us who use Windows 8/8.1 with this one. When I tried to play the game it constantly crashed without any reason and at random times. When contacted, they told me the game wasn't supported but neither Steam nor Bethesda would offer a refund for the issues.\n\nSeeing as I am stuck with the game (at least until I can get a computer able to run it without crashing) I don't recommend the game if you are running Windows 8.x, stick to 7 or lower for it. Still, fun game when I played it on my other computer.

reviewText: A must have for any Doom fan and highly reccomended for anyone who likes the FPS genre. The game comes packaged with Doom 3 and it's expansion pack as well as a new small campaign that is interquel to the main game. Additionally small graphical and gameplay tweaks are made that enhance the overall experience, such as being able to wield a weapon and use the flashlight simultaneously. A revamped save system also makes the game more forgiving on the harder difficulties. You will also find bundled the first two original Doom games complete with the Thy flesh consumed" and "No rest for the living" expansions for Doom 1 and Doom 2 respectively. Minor control tweaks are evident and are far more comfortable than older PC ports of the original two games. The graphics may seem dated by today's standards but they have a certain punk charm to them. More than anying this bundle shows how well the Doom trilogy has aged and I cannot praise this collection enough."

reviewText: I got it while it was on sale for the holidays for $4.99.  I would not recommend spending more than this for it.  I can verify that the widescreen options work perfectly with my 2560x1440 screen.  It also runs buttery smooth with 8x anti-aliasing / 16x motion blur on my gtx 970 system (can probably set these higher but it would be a case of diminishing returns at this level).  I just bought it for the better graphical options over the original release and the flashlight option.  I got exactly what I expected.  I just don't care enough about such an old game to tweak every last setting in the original release with third party mods...too much hastle.\n\nThis is very stable, runs perfectly, and looks great.  Not as great as the original will with mods and lots of time spent tweaking the graphical settings...but certainly good enough for me.  This game is a classic for me at this point, and it was definitely $4.99 well spent.  I would recommend this at that price point.  Don't waste your money if it's not on sale though.  You're getting a graphically worse game than the original-technically speaking-since it cannot be modded.

reviewText:
That's the last time I ever listen to a negative review again.

After having just beat Brutal Doom v20 (which is an amazing mod and you should check it out if your a DOOM fan), it resparked my old love of DOOM and I needed more. Seeing as how the new DOOM reboot isn't coming out for another couple months more and having never beat the original DOOM 3 because I got scared ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ a few hours in many years ago, I decided to purchase this version, and I can safely say it's scaring me ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ again and was well worth it for the 3$ I paid at Gamestop.

I've realized alot of people give this version negative remarks because of changes it made, which if you've never played the original DOOM 3 you wouldn't even notice, but honestly it doesn't bother me one bit. Initially I had a few problems with screen-tearing and random stutters, but after changing the in-game refresh rate to 120hz and turning off v-sync, my game plays perfectly and looks pretty damn nice too. I feel as if people just love to complain about any little thing, COMPLETELY disregarding all of the positive aspects and accomplishments. If you prefer to play DOOM 3 non bfg edition with mods, thats completely fine. I got this version because it came with everything I wanted in one simple package, including DOOM 1, 2, and 3, and all of the expansions for DOOM 3 for just 3 bucks, it was a steal.

Now, time to pee myself again and enjoy every second of it.

reviewText: Doom 3: BFG Edition is a masterpiece... sort of. To be honest, the only reason it's so good is because it's Doom 3. There is nothing too special about this new edition that makes it unique. Unfortunately, do not expect to get Doom 1 and 2 in this package as id Software and Bethesda advertised. The copies of D1 and D2 in this game have been defiled and censored. I seriously question the common sense of whoever made the descision to go back and censor a 20 year old game. All the Nazi refereces have been removed from the secret levels of Doom 2 (the D2 secret levels were basically recreations of levels from Wolfenstein 3D, a game that took place in a secret Nazi castle during WWII). By censoring those levels, all meaning was taken from them and now they just look like stupid blue corridors.\n\nStill, because you can get a graphically enhanced version of Doom 3, plus the Resurrection of Evil expansion pack and the all new Lost Mission"
date: the game is worth the $20 price tag that it holds at the time of writing. $20 is much less than you would spend to buy new or even used copies of D3 and RoE. I would pick it up if you liked D3. Just ignore the crappy insults to Doom 1 and 2 that they included."

reviewText:
Ok, this is my first steam review so I think I'll just break it down into pros and cons.

Pros: I guess It's a good deal considering you also get Doom, Doom 2 and Doom 3 plus some expansions. Higher resolutions and slightly higher res textures. The game runs better.

Cons: (This was a con for me, other people might like this) the game is much shorter and easier since you can now use a gun and a flashlight at the same time plus there is much more ammo and the game is brighter (why add a shoulder mounted flashlight when the game is already much brighter?). There is no mod support. Remember the cool Wolfenstein levels in Doom 2? Well they have been censored way too much, look up doom 3 bfg censorship on youtube to see what I mean. If you want 16x AA you need a NVIDIA graphics card.

So all in all, you could just mod the original to look way better than this. The only reason I recommend it is because it doen't have that weird glitch with the graphics settings that forces you to run it in low settings (anyone else get that glitch?) and it runs really smoothly.

reviewText:
You should get this game if you care about the gaming experience and not just the graphics. Graphics are normally extremely important for FPS games however in todays market they are part of the bigger picture.

It's been years since I played the original Doom3 & RoE, but since I've made the move to Steam I have committed time to completing the BFG edition.

Sure the graphics, physics, options and all of that have been decreased but there have been achievements otherwise such as Oculus Rift compatibility. The graphics are standard instead of incredible, unfortunately there's currently no mod support unless somebody was to implement it using the source code (publicly free).

Things that braught me to this one instead of Vanilla were the extras, nicer menus, the lost episode and achievements. I can always switch to Vanilla with HD textures as I own all of them - but then again I'm a huge id Software fan going back more than 20 years now and frankly I would follow them into the ground, I do love their style.

Faults? The story as everybody says is crap but it suffices. It really could have used features (even hidden) to allow mods, different texture qualities etc. Ultimately it's not a bad release, the guys complaining about how bad it looks clearly haven't made games like this before and don't have the same appreciation for the quality of gameplay and this game was constructed to be played on virtually any semi-gaming system. What they (and Carmack as programmer) set out to achieve was achieved.

The latest Wolfenstein game is the best game I have played since the release of Doom 3, and if that's anything to say for Doom 4 I truly cannot wait for its release next year!

reviewText:
Nearly all the Doom releases so far, in one package, with steam achievements. The Doom 3 in this edition is “remastered,” though not to everyone’s liking; the old Dooms are almost vanilla with a few odd tweaks that most people won’t notice. Doom purists and those that are looking to mod are both advised to avoid this.

I do recommend this for: 1) total Doom newbs looking for the simplest path forward to prepare their souls for the upcoming Doom release, 2) old-school gamers that want to replay the entire series on a modern machine through one interface and don’t want to fuss around with mods, and 3) steam achievement hunters with strong nostalgia for the series. However, I recommend this edition only if it is dirt cheap; several high-profile critics and a ton of series fans justifiably slammed it at launch for being a bad deal (to say the least) and it’s impossible to argue with that logic at the launch price. Bought dirt cheap on the other hand, no worries.

Everyone else interested in the series will likely be happier avoiding the older titles altogether and waiting to see if the upcoming reboot is any good.

Things to note:

Online multiplayer seekers: There are two Doom 3 editions on steam (BFG and standard) and they do not have interoperable multiplayer. Doom 3’s multiplayer was never anything special and the core game is over a decade old, so expect either version’s online scene to usually be totally deserted, though both versions do have players and you can stumble on an open match now and then. Doom 3 multiplayer runs notoriously bad, but if you are willing to rough it (e.g., you fondly remember the days of dial-up multiplayer) matches can be fun and unpredictable in short bursts. Seriously competitive types or those that require smooth performance to have fun will just get enraged and are advised to avoid Doom 3 multiplayer entirely. The older Dooms do not have online multiplayer through steam.

Steam achievement hunters: beware the multiplayer-dependent achievements. Note the above caveats about multiplayer and plan to either bring a couple of friends along for the ride or to join the Doom multiplayer community group in steam and actively find people to play with if you want to 100% this.

A rundown of the D3BFG package for newbs to the series:

Included in the D3BFG pack are Ultimate Doom (Doom + TFC), Doom II, and Doom II’s NRFTL expansion. Just think of all of these as more of the same game. These original Dooms are simple but satisfying monster shooting galleries where navigating the levels is itself sometimes a puzzle to be solved and difficulty ramps up as you progress with bigger and trickier ambushes of tougher and crazier monsters.

The main focus of the D3BFG pack however is Doom 3 and its expansions ROE and TLM. Doom 3 was a reboot to the original Dooms; the story, feel, and gameplay are somewhat different. Doom 3 is a hybrid between a typical FPS game of that era and a simplified survival horror game of that era. The highlights in these games are creepy atmosphere, a few good jump scares, and some cool monsters.

A quick way to get a taste of the typical gameplay of the series without dedicating a lot of hours to it is to skip straight to the last expansions for each game engine (NRFTL for original, TLM for reboot) and try to beat them on hard difficulty. These expansions provide a shorter, more condensed snapshot of the core games for those short on time. Play NRFTL on Ultra-Violence and play TLM on Veteran (1 step down from Nightmare in both, which is ridiculously hard in the original and overly frustrating in the reboot).

reviewText:
Doom; the ultimate horror gaming franchise. I've been playing Doom games ever since I could understand how to use a mouse and keyboard.

Doom 3: BFG Edition gives you Doom, Doom II, a slightly retextured Doom 3, Doom 3: Resurrection of Evil and the previously unreleased Doom 3: The Lost Mission. All of which are oustanding titles worth playing.

Doom 3 and it's expansions are a personal favorite of mine. They bring the perfect mix of what FPS games should be: Good content, immersive lore, boss fights and just enough horror to make you second guess which hallway you want to go down.

I recommend any lover of FPS or horror games purchase Doom 3: BFG Edition. It will leave you more than satisfied and you'll find it difficult to peel yourself away from the computer.

reviewText:
DOOM 1. Brilliant game play, fast action and decent map designs. What you'd expect from a 90s shoot em' up game. DOOM 2, my personal bread and butter out of the lot. Much like DOOM 1 but with better maps and more enemies. and DOOM 3 which, while good, I personally don't think it's as good as 1 and 2.  Possibly the fact that the 3D environment doesn't give the same feel or there isn't demons in your face 24/7 although their is no real shortage of action.
If I had to rate the series as a whole, I'd give 10/10. It's worth a buy for sure, full of mindless violence and a somewhat interesting concept and story, although nobody cares about that, we all just want to shoot things.

TL;DR. You get to kill tons of things and is a fast paced action pact game. Worth the buy.

reviewText:
DO NOT EVER THINK ON BUYING THIS GAME! Why, because the devs decided to make a horrible port and let it rot on the internet. I swear when this happens, its because someone didn't really care that their game was going to die if they decided to do it. I bet I could get the CD version to run in fullscreen without being forced to run in a small window. Sure, that looks good, and runs well, but I want some emersion, and seeing a box outlining the screen is Terrible. No one wants to see a screen reduced to a small pile of crap on you computer. And for those if you must know the way to run this game properly is to go into the properties on steam, set up the launch options to launch the game this way: +Set r_fullscreen  0. Like I said though, you're only getting a small screen. Some peole might luck out and put in 2-4 inplace of 0 and get their fullscreen, but me, guess I'm unlucky. Uninstalled it right after too because either way, if I am going to play a game in a small window I better be recording it or some other reason because I wouldn't have to run it just to play it in a window.

Also, just incase you made it this far on my little rant, I never really leave a review unless it KILLS me to see a game fall into the trash bin, and yes my laptop is REALLY good and close to the Up-to-date" quota to play a game like this.

My main specs:

Intel i7 core processer
Nvidia 850 GTX
16 RAM

And honestly
date: that's practically all I would need to run this game. Sure there is more I could include
recommended: but that's the bulk of what gets used on this laptop. Rest in pieces Doom 3

reviewText: Often called the weakest title in the series, Doom 3 is a satisfying shooter. Sure, there are some cheap punches pulled by Imps hiding behind doors, waiting for you to open them, granting them a free hit. However, there's a lot going on here. Some of the setpieces are honestly creepy, and the variety of weapons (albiet taken straight from previous Doom titles with the exception of the machine gun) are satisfying. The game runs well on modern machines, and has some amazing lighting effects. Doom 3: BFG Edition also includes Doom and Doom 2, and if you don't own those titles, this is an added boon. There's also several achievements to nab here, for those who hunt them. For the price, I think you can do a lot worse than Doom 3.

reviewText:
These opinions are from a guy that hasn't played Doom 3 without the BFG edition

Pros
- Scary
- Good Voice acting
- The first and second Doom come included with the episodes (Both better games)

Cons
- Weak unsatisfying weapons
- Low res-textures
- Extremely low polygon count
- Slightly predictable
- Almost no graphical adjustments
- The start of the game feels like it was completely ripped from Half Life
- You have to listen to dull audio files to get key codes
- Slow paced combat
- Tight enclosed areas
- Apparently unmoddable

Conclusion
A very unpolished game that seems like it is just trying to leech money off of its previous games’ success. The game should have been under a different title as it does not feel like a doom game in the slightest. The only thing similar in this is the items and enemies and even that’s a stretch.

reviewText:
I still remember playing Doom 3 (and the expansion) soon after it got released. It was a mediocre shooter even at the time but I liked it, it was a good abreaction when I had enough stress and wanted just to relieve it in fast and brutal shooter with zombies and demons.

I haven't felt much nostalgia about the game before starting Doom 3: BFG Edition but I have to say that the details that made me remember the game are out. It's now just shooter for nostalgic people, but I think it's not worth enough to anyone who haven't played Doom 3 back at the release year.

The first part of the game, most memorable for me, felt more like a survival horror than a brutal action since player had limited ammo and a flashlight that couldn't be toggled - if you wanted light, you just had to hold flashlight instead of weapon. That boosted the effect of many jumpscares or secret minirooms where enemies are hidden. But now you just turn on the light and shoot everything without any stress - the enemies have terrible AI anyway, so expect getting into problems only when you get overwhelmed by amount of stupid enemies (in the late game).

Sadly, I feel the graphics aged worse than in the original Doom 1 and 2 - if you are going to play the game, don't expect anything pretty or interesting. It's an ugly mars base with aliens. Oh, that even sums the whole story theme the game is about (think of the story like it'd be a porn script, it has similar depth).

I hoped I would enjoy the game in the same way like I did years ago but I can't. There are many better mindless shooters currently, so I'd rather recommend you to check Serious Sam (HD) or Painkiller series. I believe this was only fast reedition to get more money for upcoming sequel, so I'm looking forward to play the new DOOM!


For more reviews, join Samurai Vader's Point of View group and follow my curator page, I'm always happy to see feedback about my reviews.

reviewText: Remember the FPS games of old? Think back to the years of the early '90s (there were other ones in the '70s that were First-person and sort of involved shooting things but thse were arcade-only and didn't really revolve around the First-Person view) people were just checking out this kickass game called Wolfenstein 3D, a game largely credited as the Grandfather to all FPS video games. Wolfenstein 3D was focused mainly on the shooting of nazis (nobody would hate on that) and had revolutionary 3D graphics, kickass themes, etc. After the huge success, id Software created another FPS a year or two after Wolfenstein 3D. That game was DOOM, the FPS, where you are a nameless space marine on Mars battling demons from hell, as well as possessed corpses/marines, and cyborg-demons. It featured a radical soundtrack, impressive graphics (which still hold out to this day) and tight gameplay and action. It was non-stop, balls-to-the-walls action that made the players feel like a badass. After that, id software released DOOM II which still featured the main mechanics that made the original a success. It featured an improved visual, new items and weapons, and a larger soundtrack, yet was not as outstanding or culturally effective as it's predecessor. Then after many years, on August of 2004, DOOM 3 came out. It was more focused on horror and careful strategies then the run-and-gun idea of it's predecessors. It was praised for it's tension-rising atmosphere and horror, yet got negativity and criticism for it's lacking of the run-and-gun mechanic (which many loved about in DOOM 1 & 2). The entire trilogy is well-loved and enjoyed constantly. Hell, people would play this all the time AT WORK. This is the collection of not only DOOM 3 (a remastered version with some things being improved or taken out and improved graphics), and the collection also features the first and second DOOM games! If you want sci-fi horror with action sequences and gun-usage, go to DOOM 3. If you want to run-and-gun and venture through the bowels of hell and return with your life and soul intact while being titled as the dude that killed all the ♥♥♥♥ing demons on mars and beat the ♥♥♥♥ out of some huge demons with cybernetic attachments"
date: then go to DOOM I or DOOM II for that matter. This collection improved on what we loved about the franchise
recommended: and allows us to re-immerse ourselves into it all over again."

reviewText: I got this pack mainly so I could play Doom and Doom II with a controller. I figured from the start that, due to my laptop's history of not running very detailed games well, Doom 3 probably wasn't going to work. I was right. It loads up, but it makes my computer run really hard, which would eventually make it overheat and shut down. Also, it's so choppy that I couldn't really move. But I can't blame the game for that because I'm very certain it's just my own computer. Even still, just getting to play Doom and Doom II with a controller was well worth the 20 bucks I payed to get this collection. I can imagine that, if you have a machine that CAN run Doom 3, you'll probably enjoy it as another nice little bonus, or the other way around for the first two. I had a blast and don't regret this purchase. Maybe someday I'll have a more powerful computer to play Doom 3 on, but even for now, Doom and Doom II are more than enough, especially since THOSE are what I was interested in in the first place. So there you go. Even if you don't really want Doom 3 or can't run it, but still want to play the first two with a controller, this collection will still work for you and is well worth the price tag. Recommended.

reviewText:
It's the beginning of fall and the cold weather and dreary skies are rolling in. Perfect time to stay indoors and play a horror game.

I'll admit this is only mildly spicy as far as true horror gaming goes. Demons jump out and startle you but you can't really be *scared* when you play as Doomguy. He's a walking, non-talking, demon-mashing machine. And when you get the double-barrel/super shotgun? Forget it. They shoulda never given you this boomstick. And the BFG 9000? Oh my...

I want to make special note of the lighting and shadowing. Very, very well done. I don't know enough about graphics rendering and CGI to speak in technical terms about it but I really like the way the developers handled the darkness in this game. In Dead Island I upped the Gamma settings so I could see a little easier in really dark locations but that doesn't work in Doom 3. When something is in the shadow it is totally black until you shine the flashlight on it. This really got me one time when I tried to be slick at the beginning. I was practically chest-to-chest with an Imp standing in a dark corner and I didn't know it was there until I turned on the light. (Apparently it was really dedicated to making me jump because he didn't agro at all until he was sure I'd seen him.)

Doom 3 is an excellent reboot of the Doom franchise. I don't fault the developers for drastically changing the tone from shoot-em-up to survival horror. Doom 1 and 2 are solid classics, but I don't think the power-ups and colored key/door gameplay would have transitioned well to the modern era.

reviewText:
I'd recommend against this game if you're looking to play Doom 3. This version (BFG Edition) has terrible vertical sync issues and lower resolution textures than the original. They've also censored the Red Cross symbols and removed any Nazi references from the Doom II Nazi bonus levels. The biggest divergence from the original though, is allowing you to use a flashlight at the same time as your main weapon. Granted this was a frustration in the original edition, but it did make the game a lot creepier.

It's saving point is if you want to play the retro games Doom I & II on Windows 8. The regular Steam versions of these games won't run (DOSbox crashes) in Win 8. You can always just download ZDoom however if you own the original game files so this isn't much of a pro feature. Get this if you like Steam acheivements and don't mind that it's an inferior edition to the original.

Note: they reduced the textures and adjusted much of the lighting to make the game playable on the PS3 and xBox 360. If this version did not have tearing (vertical sync) issues, then it might be a viable alternative for older PC hardware but it's a mess.
