reviewText:
(Recommended with reservations)

Here is a game much maligned but it's not that bad. It has a faster, more efficient engine and comes with Doom 3 expansions Resurrection of Evil and the Lost Mission, and the first two games in the series. Lost Mission certainly does recycle art from the main campaign, but it's reasonable because the mission takes place in the same locations, concurrently to main campaign. However, all is not acceptable for this BFG edition. For example, mods for the original version of the game are unfortunately incompatible. The developer has released the tools to develop mods for this version, but as of this time, there is no easy way to upgrade the shocking textures of the vanilla game.

As for the older games, there have been slight edits to remove Red Cross trademarked material, but other than that, there are no obvious improvements. In the end, the controversy around this game is a shame, because this is a solid and enjoyable experience that is superior to the original release in many ways. Unfortunately, the game is buggy, such as when it thinks the console has been used when it hasn't; this deactivates achievements and wastes your time. It seems that the best Bethesda can offer is 'reinstall the game', and it's up to us to 'deal' with it. That is a shame.

reviewText: The straight away answer I would to give to anyone who asked me if I enjoyed the game would be yes. But do I recommend it to others? The game comes with DOOM and DOOM II, two of my favorite games of all time. I would HIGHLY recommend you purchase both of those titles, even if you decide not to buy DOOM 3: BFG Edition. The DOOM 3 part of DOOM 3: BFG Editon is DOOM 3, but with minor gameplay and graphical updates implemented. It additionally includes the two expansion packs for DOOM 3, Resurection of Evil (RoE) and The Lost Levels, and the expansion pack for DOOM II, No Rest For the Living. To allow the game to sell in Germany, the Wolfenstien 3D levels in DOOM II were additionally censored to remove the Nazi enemies and pictures of Hitler and Swastikas.\n\nDOOM 3 is a very fun game in my opinion. The games difficulty ramps up at a bit of a slow pace, but the game picks up near the end. It took me around 30 hours to complete the entire game of DOOM 3 (Not including any of the expansions or DOOM and DOOM II). The game offers a ton of enemies and weapons, and many people will try to compare it to the original DOOMs, saying that it is bad in comparison". DOOM 3 is very similar to DOOM and DOOM II

reviewText:
Update 1: This BGH version can run solid at 60fps on a retina macbook pro (1gb 650m) at crazy 2880x1800 resolution with 4x AA. It is just an amazing experience!

Doom 3 is the masterpiece of survival horror adventure and technological masterpiece of ex generation (ps3,xbox360). You can see how many titles out there (Half Life 2, Resident evil 4, dead space) r in fact influnced by the horror design featured within doom 3.

This remaster version enhanced the experience which I could not possibly before. It runs so smooth like no other fps out there on low spec modern machines.

In my memory, I could not have the right hardware to run the game at medium setting back to 2004. The mainstream monitor scale was 4:3. I bought the world first 16:9 widescreen laptop Sony Vaio in 2004. After several years release of doom 3 , I read everywhere people r buying new hardware to build a high end pc to run doom3 in ultra.It is nearly 10 years after the epic release. Now I am able to run it on a laptop with 650m 1gb vram at 1440p max at 60fps.

One thing worth to mention is that I did NOT play doom 3 much deeper than 30minutes progress in 2004. I was scared by the ultra realistic creepy monsters.

In 2014, it is still scary as hell but due to better maturity mind now I can play the game without hiding underseat. Another factor could be my soul has already survived through other horror games these years (eg.resident evil 4, dead space 3).

As an epic masterpiece,  Doom 3 is still providing an authentic scary experience and fresh if you did not play it (much) before like me previously.

reviewText:
Definitely worth a buy. Originally did not like this game, but grew to love it due to the environments. I think I like BFG Edition even more. I've read all the complaints. Some of them are valid (or were valid before fixes were implemented) but a lot of them weren't... such as brightness levels (looks better now), ammo count (it's true that the whole PDA thing is optional now most of the time because you're never short on ammo, but it means the game is more action-packed and faster-paced), reworked menus (they look and control better now, in my opinion -- also like the new Doom 3 logo much better). Etc..

It also controls better. Seems much more responsive and faster due to the increased framerate and probably other improvements they made. Motion blurring is a nice addition, too.

Classic Dooms are ported well and appear high resolution (can see sprites clearly at a distance). Also controls well with everything set up for modern WASD controls. The No Rest for the Living" episode by Nerve is quite good (already available on Xbox 360). Overall this port is a lot better than some of the detractors said it was. Even the music in Doom Classic seems pretty good-- I notice it has Gravis sound files in the Steam folders."

reviewText: I olay this game on Big Picture and I thoroughly enjoy it.  I love playing Doom I and Doom II on a controller while I sit on my coach.  Doom still holds up as a playable experience after 20 years.  The changes to Doom 3 are welcome. Among the changes are graphical upgrades (motion blur, post processing effects) and gameplay changes ( the Doomguy now has a chest-mounted flashlight/torch).  While the original Doom 3 campaign is predictable and slow, the new episode has a much faster pace with and emphasis on action rather than atmosphere.  It's a fun experience that is hindered only by the fact that it is very short -- I finished it in less than 5 hours.

reviewText:
Bought it for $4.99 on Daily Deal.  Well worth the purchase.  I am very surprised by how enjoyable this game is.

At first I thought this game would be the same old shooter with jump scares and hidden hallways, and I was right....
However, the way they carried the sub-par story through the game is spectacular, and makes all the difference.  Everything has its place, and the video logs and emails through your PAL bring a fantastic level of emersion.  I like how the game is able to poke fun at itself, at science, and even at something unexpected like work politics or D&D.  The levels are fun; fighting the creatures is fun; the game is fun.
What I enjoyed most is despite how far the game has come since Doom II, the game kept much of the spirit of its predecessors throughout.  It actually reminded me of playing a Doom II level.  I love the unique ways they make the monsters blind side you, and just when I thought I got the “jump scares” figured out, Doom 3 in classic fashion surprises you.  The game literally had me checking every corner of every room before I progressed for tucked away hidden monster waiting to ambush.  The darkness, although a bit much, was still extremely appropriate and well done.  I’m so glad they made the flashlight something you wear, rather than an item to switch in and out with like they had on the previous Doom 3 (TERRIBLE IDEA GUYS!!).  The use of light and space was masterful and suspenseful.

What I don’t like about Doom 3 is there are only a select few collection of monsters to encounter.  Once you’ve figured out how to deal with them, the only challenge left is managing an entire room’s worth of them.  I would love to have seen twice as many different types of monsters as was shown (especially since this is a reboot).  I also didn’t like the ending.  It didn’t feel “epic” enough.  It was very easy.  There weren’t too many side characters to interact with, nor were there very many puzzles.  Remembering a scrap paper’s-worth of Storage Container access codes does NOT make it a puzzle. :/  Finally, while the animation of the monsters was beautiful, the animation of the npc’s and yourself was abysmal.  Some of the worst dubbing I’ve seen with newer-generation graphics.  The character designs of npc’s were boring, re-used for multiple different characters, and distracting.  With the reboot they really should have upgraded the animation quality, if nothing else the speech animation.

Regardless of the above, I overall really enjoyed the experience Doom 3 has to offer.  I am happy with my purchase and my game.  I’d give it a 7.2/10.

reviewText:
I hadn't played Doom 3 in ages, so I decided to buy this on sale and give it a whirl. I didn't see the comments regarding issues on AMD systems, but I've played for a couple of hours now and I haven't run into a single glitch, bug or crash. Not even a stutter in framerate. This is on a 100% AMD build (FX-8350 and Radeon 7950). I'll update my review at a later date once I've done a full playthrough of this version, but so far no problems.

So it runs fine, how does it look? Well, Doom 3 holds up pretty nicely, actually. I don't mind playing classics with dated graphics (I play through the original Doom games once a year) but this still looks nice even today. I think it's down to the hard shadows and the moody lighting. They've tweaked things in this BFG Edition, making things less dark, but it isn't bright, it's just... well, less dark! It's still dark as hell though, so don't think for a moment that they've ruined it by turning all the lights on, they haven't, it's still Doom3 and you'll still use your flashlight a lot.

Gameplay wise it's solid. If you like old school shooter action you'll probably love Doom 3 BFG. It's cramped and dark and things jump out at you regularly. At first it's simply a case of turn and shoot, but things soon amp up and you'll quickly find yourself ducking and weaving around fireballs, crouching behind cover and running around pillars to get that all important point-blank shotgun kill. In many ways it's just like the original Doom, only now you can't strafe from a safe distance, it's all up-close and personal - the hellspawn are rarely more than 10ft away from you in this game and your reaction times will be tested more than they ever were in the original.

Downsides? There have been couple of times where I found myself wishing I had a melee button to knock enemies back, but I know that would change the gameplay siginficantly. Not having a melee means even slow, lumbering, unarmed zombies can do damage if you let them get up close, and if you don't keep your wits about you, that can happen easily. You need to check every corner, keep your flashlight juiced up, keep your ears open. It's what makes Doom 3 Doom 3.

Do I recommend Doom 3 BFG Edition? Yes. The core gameplay is solid and the game still has the ability to put the ♥♥♥♥♥ up you. Don't expect a sweeping, epic storyline. Don't expect to see huge awe-inspiring vistas that stretch for miles - this is Doom 3 and everything is within spitting distance (not what you'd want when the minions of hell are after your blood).

4/5

reviewText:
I hadn't played Doom 3 in ages, so I decided to buy this on sale and give it a whirl. I didn't see the comments regarding issues on AMD systems, but I've played for a couple of hours now and I haven't run into a single glitch, bug or crash. Not even a stutter in framerate. This is on a 100% AMD build (FX-8350 and Radeon 7950). I'll update my review at a later date once I've done a full playthrough of this version, but so far no problems.

So it runs fine, how does it look? Well, Doom 3 holds up pretty nicely, actually. I don't mind playing classics with dated graphics (I play through the original Doom games once a year) but this still looks nice even today. I think it's down to the hard shadows and the moody lighting. They've tweaked things in this BFG Edition, making things less dark, but it isn't bright, it's just... well, less dark! It's still dark as hell though, so don't think for a moment that they've ruined it by turning all the lights on, they haven't, it's still Doom3 and you'll still use your flashlight a lot.

Gameplay wise it's solid. If you like old school shooter action you'll probably love Doom 3 BFG. It's cramped and dark and things jump out at you regularly. At first it's simply a case of turn and shoot, but things soon amp up and you'll quickly find yourself ducking and weaving around fireballs, crouching behind cover and running around pillars to get that all important point-blank shotgun kill. In many ways it's just like the original Doom, only now you can't strafe from a safe distance, it's all up-close and personal - the hellspawn are rarely more than 10ft away from you in this game and your reaction times will be tested more than they ever were in the original.

Downsides? There have been couple of times where I found myself wishing I had a melee button to knock enemies back, but I know that would change the gameplay siginficantly. Not having a melee means even slow, lumbering, unarmed zombies can do damage if you let them get up close, and if you don't keep your wits about you, that can happen easily. You need to check every corner, keep your flashlight juiced up, keep your ears open. It's what makes Doom 3 Doom 3.

Do I recommend Doom 3 BFG Edition? Yes. The core gameplay is solid and the game still has the ability to put the ♥♥♥♥♥ up you. Don't expect a sweeping, epic storyline. Don't expect to see huge awe-inspiring vistas that stretch for miles - this is Doom 3 and everything is within spitting distance (not what you'd want when the minions of hell are after your blood).

4/5

reviewText:
Doom 3: BFG Edition is the last game released by id Software under the technical guidance of John Carmack.

This version of Doom 3 uses a modified idTech 4 engine that takes advantage of a few rendering techniques that were developed for id's 2011 game, Rage.

Doom 3 is a game that was released over 8 years ago, so the price of the BFG Edition can make it a tough sell. But if you've never played Doom 3 then this is the version to get. Even today, it's a solid action-filled game in nearly every respect: great weapons, great combat, and great map design.

If you've played the original release, it's worth knowing that the visual enhancements, modified ammo & health placements, and armor-mounted flashlight turn this into a game that's very different from the one you knew; it now feels like a full-on action game in the vein of the classic Doom games.
(The only thing to be aware of is that this version of the game *does not* have modding or map editing support.)

Lastly, if you have a 120hz monitor (even if you don't, but especially if you do) you need this game! It looks exceptionally beautiful running at 120 frames per second on a 120hz monitor. Seriously, it's breathtaking.

reviewText: I like Doom 3, and this is the definitive version. It's Doom 3, the expansion pack Resurrection of Evil, some previously-unreleased levels called The Lost Mission, and the XBLA ports of Doom and Doom 2, complete with a new Doom 2 episode, No Rest for the Living. All of this, with all of the achievements from the Xbox 360 games. If you're into Doom, this is a great package. Doom 3 isn't the looker that it was on release, but the gameplay is still fun. Despite the monster closets, which are rampant through the main Doom 3 campaign, the action feels great. The original release of Doom 3 required you to choose between holding a weapon and holding a flashlight, which was sometimes inconvenient as there were a lot of dark areas in Doom 3 that were full of monsters. For some people, it was annoying enough to stop playing. BFG edition lets you use the flashlight at any time. Also, No Rest for the Living is a fantastic addition to Doom 2.\n\nOverall, it's a great package for anyone who likes Doom. I'd also recommend it to anyone who likes classic action games.

reviewText: Back in the days, I bought Doom 3 thinking it would be as good as the first one and the second one but oh boy, was I wrong. Maybe the graphics are not that bad, but it is as though you are just running around the same place over and over. A.I. is horrible and even though some parts of the game are kind of scary, you can tell the game was kind of cheaply made. The gameplay is just tedious and I miss the long ranged shotgun from the original Doom 1 and 2, that was just so overpowered and yet, so satisfying to kill enemies with. The shotgun is almost useless unless you are close to the enemy, and the story...is almost non-existent. It is just one of those mindless shooting games, but really, even though Doom 1 and 2 belong to that category, they still are far superior to this. I'm glad BFG Edition at least includes both 1 and 2. For Doom 1 and 2, I give 9/10. For 3, 5/10.

reviewText:
Doom 3

While it's true this game is a departure from the series roots, doom 3 isn't a bad game. With a focus now on horror as well as gunplay the game widens its scope to many fans disappointment. However the graphical quantum leap from the original 1-2 lends its self to the horror atmosphere quite well. The scares may be few (if there at all) but the atmosphere is immesrive and the gunplay is fun (when dealing with the non human enemies anyway).

The game invokes total recall flashbacks from mars and even gives a nod to blade runners 2019 blaster. Keeping features from the original, doom marine still hauls a small armies worth of weapons including a chain, plasma gun and even the beloved chainsaw.

Unnecessary cutscenes occasionally pop up and temporarily break all immersion as if halflife never happened as far as the devs are concerned. Doom marine also appears to own gordons short battery flashlight which becomes crucial in darker parts of the levels... only gordon was never exposed to as much dark, thankfully it's quick to recharage and not much of an issue. Another trivial but noteworthy complaint is how quickly bodies disappear almost immediately after they hit the ground. as if the germs on the floor were more deadly than your bullets.

Doom 3 is fun just don't expect the same speed or intention of the originals. If you're a doom vet and long to zip around the halls like the glory days, this game's not for you (there's even a sprint bar now). As it stands alone though doom 3 is worth playing.

reviewText:
Doom 3 BFG edition brings hell straight to your home computer. After almost 18 hours playing through Doom 1, 2, and 3, this is my final verdict following all three games.

Doom (the original game)
- Doom was a great classic, I recommend it to any traditional PC gamer looking for some old school entertainment.

Doom 2
- The second game in the Doom series has a lot of similarities with the original Doom installment. Only I found the game much harder than the original. Even on a normal difficulty enemies are much more difficult to take down and heath is much harder to find.

Doom 3
- Dooms third installment was something else compared to the other two games. Id software did a good job of innovating while staying true to the original Doom feeling. Id managed to step out and innovate their game by changing the traditional level design to a more realistic take on the Mars research base. Though the level design not only made me feel more immersed in the game, it also had a couple of down sides. When given an objective the player would need to move through a series of rooms until he / she reached that objective. But doing so would get repetitive as the level design follows the same four steps : enter room -> enemies spawn -> player kills enemies -> player enters next room. Along side this most of the enemies become very simple to kill as two shots from a shotgun will likely take most enemies out. I'm happy to see that a classic game company like Id software had the nutz to change up their game from a run and gun, to more of a moderate paced shooter, with some creepy horror aspects mixed in. Oh and this game had a bad ♥♥♥ ending if anyone was already wondering.

[Final verdict]

After many late summer nights and alot of game saves i'm happy to say that Doom 3 BFG edition wasn't half bad. Doom 3 has had a graphical overhaul since the release of BFG edtion and a small number of  in game tweaks, such as the ablity to use a flash light with your gun, and a couple of enemy model changes. I cant say Doom 3 was close to as good as some games ive played, but I think along with the graphics upgrade and Doom 1, and 2 being included, I think BFG edition is well worth the money paid.

If you made it this far thanks for reading folks
- Mojo

reviewText:
It's so much better than you remember.
Playing through Doom 3 again will make you see the game in a whole different light.   It is no longer the game that Half Life 2 made look like a gaming relic upon its release.
Doom 3 BFG edition takes the original game and makes subtle tweaks to it.  Each of these tweaks combine to make the core game a whole different experience for the player.
The original game was a slow, methodical  shooter.   It was more of a first-person survival horror game than an action shooter. The game gave you just enough ammo to survive if you checked every nook and cranny and opened every locked cabinet.    Miss too many shots, and you had to rely on your fists.   You never felt safe.  You never felt in control of the situation.   It was a great game, but it never felt like Doom".
Doom 3 BFG edition addresses this in various ways.
First
date: the game is brighter.   The original games' shadows were the centerpiece to its graphics engine.   It was like nothing you ever saw before.   Today
recommended: it's run of the mill stuff.   BFG edition reduces the shadows.   This changes the feel of the game immensely.\nSecond
hoursPlayed: they added ammo.   Playing through Doom 3 BFG edition
voteText: I don't believe I ever had a situation where I felt like I had to conserve ammo.   The ability to feel free to blow the crap out of enemies made Doom 3 BFG an absolute blast.\n\nSo
helpfulPercent: should you buy this game?\nIf you have never played Doom 3
votesHelpful:
I would suggest you play it first.
It's an game that every gamer should experience.   It's a masterwork of atmosphere.  The ammo deficit is also masterfully done.   It rewards firing accuracy and slow movement.    It's survival horror at its best.

But...after you have played the original doom
votesTotal: go back and play the BFG edition.   It will make you appreciate just how well Doom 3 did what it was designed to do

reviewText:
A nice bundle buy that will leave you entertained for a good while if you're into the games in their vanilla states.

Doom 3's lost a lot of its horror aspects thanks to its new mounted flashlight capability, but the first playthroughs should have you feeling uneasy and claustaphobic. The graphics are nice, as well as the majority of the sound design. The double barreled shotgun leaves a lot to be desired though, as well as the Grabber in the expansion campaigns.

The classic games are still fun, but the labyrinth-like levels might frustrate people who are used to the linear design style used today. It seems as if they gradually become more annoying the farther you get though.

If you want more bang for your buck, you might want to pick up the standalone games when they're on sale - so you can look into modding 'em. If that's not your thing, I'd still recommend this.

reviewText:
Doom 1, 2 and 3 in one game.
It's simply amazing but I'd suggest you to buy the original games instead of the BFG Edition because of some changes.


Doom 1 review: 9.5/10
Doom 2 review 9.5/10
Doom 3 review 8.0/10


Personally, Doom 3 isn't that great In my opinion, it is good, really good but not as much as the first and the second were, heck, even some mods are better.
It's different but it's great.
I won't make a big paragraph about the Doom games because if you are looking at this review, you should already know what this game is all about.
Action, action, carnage, action, pure action, pure fun, pure carnage, killing spree, pure old-school shooter, greatness, challenging at the highest difficulty, score to beat (by finding secrets, beating your best time), by killing every enemies, etc etc...)

If you love Doom and you'd love more like this but you do not know where to start or what to play then look at this list.
It's my personal list of old-school shooters (that plays exactly or almost the same, no Doom 3 like game), here's some of them, not all but some good ones.

Quake and Quake II.
Redneck Rampage series.
Blood One.
Wolfenstein 3D.
Duke Nukem 3D.
Spear of Destiny.
Star Wars: Dark Forces.
Rise of the Triad.
Heretic.
Hexen series
Blake Stone series.
System Shock.
Marathon series.
NAM.
WWII GI.
Shadow Warrior (the 1997 edition).
Exhumed AKA PowerSlave.
Witchaven.

I may be forgetting some but that's already a big list.

You'll love The Elder Scrolls I: Arena and The Elder Scrolls II: Daggerfall if you love the old-school gameplay and role-playing games.

But when a Teleportation Experment goes astary due to a terrible accident, Phobos Base sends out a distress signal while Deimos Base drops dead & disappears completely. Responding to a frantic distress call from the overrun scientists, the Martian marine unit is quickly sent by ship from Mars to Phobos to investigate, only to find the Phobos Completely overrun by devilspawns from the Gates of Hell & there's one option left: LOCK & LOAD!

reviewText: Doom 3 Doom 3 itself is a fun game with its claustrophobic, tight corridors and combat with it's terrifying demons. What makes this edition great is that is comes with both DLCs, and that they branch off of the main story line and show you different experiences with different people. Doom 3 offers some spooky atmosphere and plenty of jumpscares. I'd reccommend this game if you are looking for action, jumpscares, and a hellish tone. Doom 3 is a great single player game, but sadly you won't find anyone playing multiplayer.\n\nDoom 1 & 2 Doom 1 and 2 practically play the exact same: the shoot 'em up type of thing. They're pretty fun to play, but I spent more time in Doom 3 because I found it more fun. Doom 1 and 2 don't actually have a story, but it's pretty fun to just run around really quickly blasting your foes away.

reviewText:
Why mess up Doom 3 ID ?

So here's what wrong with Doom 3 BFG:
- Ultra Quality texture from the original Doom 3 are missing (They Look like ♥♥♥♥ in the BFG edition).
- Removing the Flashlight (Big mistake if you ask me).
- Default Fov Is 60 (ID are you crazy poor console players) when on the original Pc and original xbox version supported a better Field Of Fiew.
- It's Way too demanding in Pc Spec to run it (It's a 2004 game, compare the spec to Half Life 2).
- Windows vista and Windows 7 (That kinda dumb considering that Rage runs on windows XP).
- No online Co-op for the Campaign (when the original Xbox Version had that feature).
- No red cross on the health pack of Doom and Doom II (That dumb censorship).
- No advantage taken from the Rage engine (so why use this engine).

So here what Doom 3 BFG gets right:
- Hud and Pad have been reworked for widescreen resolution support.
- Doom and Doom II included
- Super Turbo Turkey Puncher 3 is still included in the Campaign
- Expansion ROE and a New Bonus campaign is added to give a better value to the BFG packaging
- Support up to 120 fps
- Gamepad support

5.9/10 Verdic: I love Doom 3 It's in my top Best Video Game List but I cannot recommend this release.
Do yourself a favor and buy the original Doom 3, Mod it and stay away from Doom 3 BFG.

reviewText:
Pros:

- Nice atmosphere and scenario.
- Interesting story.
- Challenging boss fights.
- Not-too-heavy requirements.
- Well, it's Doom. And it contains Doom 1+2.

Cons:

- No cloud save. I lost my save suddenly when I was using CCleaner. Seriously, is that a difficult thing to implement?
- Not improved graphics compare to original Doom 3.
- Unstable FPS at some points.
- Still a buggy game. I couldn't get achievements just because I changed the FOV within Settings menu (no, I'm not kidding).

Well, with Doom 1 and 2 included, I think you should get it when it's on sale (about $5 or so). Otherwise, get the original version.

reviewText:
Doom 3 is an amazing game that has grown to be a favourite of mine.
When I was younger, I used to get uncomfortable and edgy playing this game, and never managed to finish it.
Playing Doom 3 in the dark with 5.1 surround can be somewhat frightening...
I recently beat it though after all these years and had some fun with it on Steam.

Anyway, you are here for a review on this...pure dog turd of a remake.

I'm writing this assuming and hoping you are familiar with Doom 3.
Maybe you've played it, or maybe you've beaten it, but I'm sure you recall some of the core mechanics of the game.
Basic features like ZOOM, and changing FOV in the console to that exact # that works for you were second nature.
Regularily used gameplay mechanics like swapping to the infinite power flashlight to see around those dark corners, then swapping back to your gun also were forced to become second nature to you as you played.

Well, this game gives you a middle finger when you attempt to use the console now, with a big message that shows up telling you that since you accessed the console" you will no longer earn "steam achievments" in this save.
Excuse me!? All I did was change my FOV
date: and this is what happens?\nIf you don't care about achievements
hoursPlayed:
but that is part of the reason I wanted this game and being told off for changing FOV is not appreciated.
Strike 1.

Can you believe it? They removed the ZOOM function for everything. You can NO LONGER ZOOM in a first person shooter. You could zoom in doom 3 and pretty much every other FPS
voteText:
but here? NO!? WHAT?
Strike 2.

So

reviewText:
The multiplayer in the original Doom 3 is a lot of fun and has a high skill ceiling. The multiplayer in D3BFG is almost the same thing, but worse. In Doom 3 BFG Edition, you can't call votes, so to change maps in a private match, you have to leave the match and start a new one, but if you're doing public games, then you're usually locked into the same map for several matches in a row; you can leave a public match all you want, but clicking quick match to try and get a different map will likely just put you back into the match you just left. The way public matches work is terrible, you click quick match or find match and if no one is playing, you become the host and are put into an empty lobby. The game then randomly cycles through maps and then when someone joins it locks into the map and then you wait a long thirty seconds before you can start playing. That's right, if you're starting a public match, you can't choose the map. As far as I know, starting a private match will keep that match open only to those who are invited, so starting private matches result in truly private matches, so that's not even a workaround.

The game is a laggy mess. It has no dedicated server support, instead it has a system where one guy gets to be host and has 0 ping and then most of everyone else has some ridiculously bad ping like 350. If you're lucky you'll get 150 ping, which is still awful. If you're not hosting, you probably have a terrible ping, and because of that terrible ping, rockets and plasma become useless weapons and you pretty much have to rely on hitscan weapons like shotgun, chaingun, and machine gun. Speaking of machine gun, everyone spawns with the machine gun (MG) in this game. Some servers in the original Doom 3 spawn you with the MG, and it's not a problem in the original Doom 3 because that game isn't laggy, and actually has servers. However, spawning with MG in Doom 3 BFG Edition brings on truly frustrating gameplay where everyone spams MG off of spawn AND ACTUALLY SUCCEEDS IN GETTING KILLS WITH EASE. I'll explain.

If you're shot in the back with MG, you're probably going to die no matter what you do. The terrible netcode just does whatever the heck and then you're blasted with MG damage all of the sudden. The amount of screen shaking you get when you take MG damage is very high, and your movement can actually be hampered. I'm convinced that the ridiculous knockback and the excessive jolting of your view were not intended to be so awful; being dealt all of that stuff at a strangely rapid rate has to be a result of bad netcode and lag. It's very disorienting. Ducking behind a corner or trying to retaliate usually won't help, you'll just die. The original Doom 3 has some screen shaking when you're hit by MG, but the BFG Edition is just way worse. Another bad thing about the BFG Edition is that up to eight players can play at once in a match no matter what map is being played; the MG spam reaches truly obnoxious levels when you've got eight people running around a small map, like Delta Labs.

The chaingun was nerfed. They decreased the firing rate and didn't even lower the spread, so good luck hitting anyone that isn't running in a straight line. The double barreled shotgun is utterly useless when you're playing in a match that you're not hosting; you fire the gun, the pellets fly out half a second later, and then usually the gun doesn't even autoreload like it would if you were hosting. Obviously these issues with the double barreled shotgun are caused by the poor connection that you'll get when you're not hosting.

There are leaderboards. Each multiplayer map has their own set of leaderboards; every mode that can be played on a particular map has it's own leaderboard. For example: the map Delta Labs has four different leaderboards associated with it; there are four modes that can be played on that map. But the CTF maps were designed for CTF play only, so the CTF maps only have leaderboards that cover the CTF mode. To move up the leaderboards you have to meet some bizarre criteria. From what I've heard you have to win several matches in a row, and the more matches you win in a row, the more points you get, and the more points you have, the higher up the leaderboard you are. You don't get to see how many points you're accumulating while you're in a match, by the way; that stuff is tracked internally, it's a total mystery to you when you're actually playing. You have to check the leaderboards afterwards to see how many points you have. That's annoying.

To my knowledge, this criteria isn't confirmed, but I was told that this is what the leaderboards track, and it seems to be true, from my experience. Why do the leaderboards track that? Who cares about winning several matches in a row? High rankings on the leaderboards are a testament to your skill and experience in some way, but couldn't they have made leaderboards that track some other sort of thing? Also, it seems that the only way to get your results submitted to the leaderboard is to host the match, and then keep playing until everyone else leaves. Once everyone else leaves, then you can leave and your results will be submitted to the leaderboard. I'm pretty sure that if you do it any other way (for example, playing in a match that you're not hosting) your match results won't be submitted. Horrible.

I can think of multiple things they could've done with the multiplayer: dedicated servers, ranked modes, ranked matchmaking, statistics tracking, and leaderboards that actually matter. Instead they put ZERO effort into the multiplayer component and in the process actually made it WORSE than the multiplayer in the original Doom 3. I can't believe they charged $40 for this at one point.

reviewText:
The big thing to know with this edition is a simple pro/con,

Pro-Get all the doom games in one place

Con-Much less Mod friendly EDIT-Doom 1 and 2 work fine with mods, get brutal doom for a wonderfully enhanced gameplay experience (As in, better than ALOT of modern shooters, so many features, fatalities, sounds that make your ears... you get it, BANG, HACK, BWAHAHA! FEAR ME HELL, I AM YOUR RECKONING!<--makes you feel like this)

As for Each game?

DooM
I dont need to say much, this is the grandaddy of most shooters today and is still fun to play. not at all scary by todays standards but its a different experience compared to the reload and take cover FPS trend we all suffer through daily. Doom is a game where your only hope is to move faster, react faster, and strafe your enemies until they die, no hiding and waiting for health to recharge.

DooM 2
Like doom one, but with a few new baddies, and it has the Super Shotgun... which is the best gun in any videogame, ever

DooM 3

This isnt a bad game... but its not a doom game. DooM 3 feels like a wannabe half life two, with many similar features, a plot based on teleporting gone to hell (literally) a grabber/gravity gun weapon, etc. You move very slow and the levels are cramped as hell so its usually a matter of seeing them and blasting them while trying to miracle your way around fireballs in tight corridors. This games biggest victory is in the fact that it may have taught Bethesda what to make DooM 4. DooM 3 is advertised as a horror game, but most people wont be scared at any point in the game (though one glitch did make me jump, where a random zombie materialized in front of me at random, not in the proper spawn style)

The enemies in DooM 3 typically spawn through portals that pop up when you enter areas or take things, and killing them usually means sitting next to the portal until they are vulnerable and then blasting them with a shotgun. The shotgun in DooM has a limited ammo supply, especially when compared to the fact there are 3 rapid fire weapons of realitive similarity (chain gun, assault rifle, plasma gun) that all get 600 rounds each, meaning you will always be out of ammo for the shotgun and never out for anything else (sans big guns). The super shotgun only appears in the RoE expansion, so if you are a nut about two barrels like me that may bug you.

All in all, this is a great pack to get for people who want to join the doom legion, and get a taste of what games used to be, what spawned all the doom clones that later evolved into the modern FPS. DooM 3, as i said, is not a bad game, its just not a doom game, its more comparable to Half life 2 or Red faction in terms of gameplay, with you able to carry a ton of guns, no recharging health mechanic, an armor mechanic, and you have to reload and move relatively slow (in the original DooM games, people spread rumors the Marine was a parapalegic in a rocket powered wheelchair since he moved so fast and couldnt jump or crouch)

I do have one big upset with doom 3 though, no subtitles, and most of the time the Transmissions" that make up the story come in when you are blasting things and you never hear them
date: what the hell is up with no subtitles?"

reviewText:
This pussified version of Doom 3 brightens the game world considerably, removes the flashlight mechanic, and doubles the amount of available ammo, turning it into a cake-walk. I breezed through it on Veteran difficulty. If you've never played it before I'd recommend the original instead. If you have played the original, well, it's still Doom 3-- lengthy campaign, fun combat, runs like a dream on modern systems and the new achievements make it worth another go-around.

Also included is the first expansion pack, Resurrection of Evil: a quality add-on, but also simplified in depressing ways. Certain areas have been removed for whatever reason, and you no longer need oxygen to traverse the toxic sections, completely removing the suspense. There's the Lost Missions, a brand new expansion exclusive to the BFG edition, which is essentially the Blue Shift" of the two in which you play a surviving Alpha Squad marine attempting to shut down the portal. Highly recommended if you can't get enough Doom 3.

Then there's Doom 1 and 2. These are both legendary shooters that have been modified to run on modern computers without the need for source-ports like Zdoom or Boom. Unfortunately
date: that means they also lack a quicksave function
hoursPlayed: or the ability to jump. The aiming system is also a little off. I did appreciate the new variety of monster dialogue
voteText: a healthy combination of remixed growls and grunts. Doom is far from perfect-- sometimes it takes one shotgun blast to kill an Imp
helpfulPercent: but other times it takes two. The second two episodes feel thrown together and pale in comparison to Knee Deep in the Dead and the more recent Thy Flesh Consumed . Lastly
votesHelpful: the invisio-sphere is still the most useless powerup in the history of FPS. It causes enemies to miss-- sometimes. If you like to strafe left and right like an OLDSCHOOL FPS PLAYER this means that nine times out of ten you will sidestep DIRECTLY INTO ENEMY FIRE.\n\nDoom 2 is a tedious bore and I could never understand the appeal of it. The maps are giant mazes that lack any sort of context. I only ever used it to mod levels with the new enemies and Super Shotgun. This version
votesTotal: however
votesFunny: contains another brand-new episode
commentsCount: "No Rest For The Living

reviewText:
Doom and Doom II: Hail to the king, baby!

just milestones in gaming history and part of my childhood. With Doom 3 BFG edition" you get all content by id software for Doom and Doom II.

Doom 3: it's ok.

Doom 3 BFG edition is a good updated version of the "original" Doom 3. Better grafics and better sound. But still the same gameplay that makes Doom 3 not feel like a "real" Doom. It's more like a "Survival / Horror Shooter". It might feel a little repedetive after a while and the enemy engagements are usualy pretty easy. Most of the times you only face one or two enemies. It's getting more chellanging in the last third of the game and on higher difficulties though - but it's still a fun game after all. The BFG edition also contains the expansion "Resurrection of Evil" and "The lost missions" which are awesome when you've enjoyed the main game.
The only thing that realy bothered me about the "BFG Edition" is the f*cking flashlight! The updated flashlight takes away alot of the original games atmosphere
date: gameplay and makes it somehow easier. If you already own copies of Doom and Doom II you should probably go for the original version of Doom 3 and it's expansions."

reviewText:
The multiplayer in the original Doom 3 is a lot of fun and has a high skill ceiling. The multiplayer in D3BFG is almost the same thing, but worse. In Doom 3 BFG Edition, you can't call votes, so to change maps in a private match, you have to leave the match and start a new one, but if you're doing public games, then you're usually locked into the same map for several matches in a row; you can leave a public match all you want, but clicking quick match to try and get a different map will likely just put you back into the match you just left. The way public matches work is terrible, you click quick match or find match and if no one is playing, you become the host and are put into an empty lobby. The game then randomly cycles through maps and then when someone joins it locks into the map and then you wait a long thirty seconds before you can start playing. That's right, if you're starting a public match, you can't choose the map. As far as I know, starting a private match will keep that match open only to those who are invited, so starting private matches result in truly private matches, so that's not even a workaround.

The game is a laggy mess. It has no dedicated server support, instead it has a system where one guy gets to be host and has 0 ping and then most of everyone else has some ridiculously bad ping like 350. If you're lucky you'll get 150 ping, which is still awful. If you're not hosting, you probably have a terrible ping, and because of that terrible ping, rockets and plasma become useless weapons and you pretty much have to rely on hitscan weapons like shotgun, chaingun, and machine gun. Speaking of machine gun, everyone spawns with the machine gun (MG) in this game. Some servers in the original Doom 3 spawn you with the MG, and it's not a problem in the original Doom 3 because that game isn't laggy, and actually has servers. However, spawning with MG in Doom 3 BFG Edition brings on truly frustrating gameplay where everyone spams MG off of spawn AND ACTUALLY SUCCEEDS IN GETTING KILLS WITH EASE. I'll explain.

If you're shot in the back with MG, you're probably going to die no matter what you do. The terrible netcode just does whatever the heck and then you're blasted with MG damage all of the sudden. The amount of screen shaking you get when you take MG damage is very high, and your movement can actually be hampered. I'm convinced that the ridiculous knockback and the excessive jolting of your view were not intended to be so awful; being dealt all of that stuff at a strangely rapid rate has to be a result of bad netcode and lag. It's very disorienting. Ducking behind a corner or trying to retaliate usually won't help, you'll just die. The original Doom 3 has some screen shaking when you're hit by MG, but the BFG Edition is just way worse. Another bad thing about the BFG Edition is that up to eight players can play at once in a match no matter what map is being played; the MG spam reaches truly obnoxious levels when you've got eight people running around a small map, like Delta Labs.

The chaingun was nerfed. They decreased the firing rate and didn't even lower the spread, so good luck hitting anyone that isn't running in a straight line. The double barreled shotgun is utterly useless when you're playing in a match that you're not hosting; you fire the gun, the pellets fly out half a second later, and then usually the gun doesn't even autoreload like it would if you were hosting. Obviously these issues with the double barreled shotgun are caused by the poor connection that you'll get when you're not hosting.

There are leaderboards. Each multiplayer map has their own set of leaderboards; every mode that can be played on a particular map has it's own leaderboard. For example: the map Delta Labs has four different leaderboards associated with it; there are four modes that can be played on that map. But the CTF maps were designed for CTF play only, so the CTF maps only have leaderboards that cover the CTF mode. To move up the leaderboards you have to meet some bizarre criteria. From what I've heard you have to win several matches in a row, and the more matches you win in a row, the more points you get, and the more points you have, the higher up the leaderboard you are. You don't get to see how many points you're accumulating while you're in a match, by the way; that stuff is tracked internally, it's a total mystery to you when you're actually playing. You have to check the leaderboards afterwards to see how many points you have. That's annoying.

To my knowledge, this criteria isn't confirmed, but I was told that this is what the leaderboards track, and it seems to be true, from my experience. Why do the leaderboards track that? Who cares about winning several matches in a row? High rankings on the leaderboards are a testament to your skill and experience in some way, but couldn't they have made leaderboards that track some other sort of thing? Also, it seems that the only way to get your results submitted to the leaderboard is to host the match, and then keep playing until everyone else leaves. Once everyone else leaves, then you can leave and your results will be submitted to the leaderboard. I'm pretty sure that if you do it any other way (for example, playing in a match that you're not hosting) your match results won't be submitted. Horrible.

I can think of multiple things they could've done with the multiplayer: dedicated servers, ranked modes, ranked matchmaking, statistics tracking, and leaderboards that actually matter. Instead they put ZERO effort into the multiplayer component and in the process actually made it WORSE than the multiplayer in the original Doom 3. I can't believe they charged $40 for this at one point.

reviewText:
Doom 3.
While a rather large departure from the series style, it's still a game I have always enjoyed. Pre-ordering it back in 2004 and being so excited to load it up the day it released.

I love the change in style. The slower pace, the horror themed to the hell invasion. Doom 3 always will be one of my favorite games.

But, the BFG Edition... how does it stand?
Well, in contains not only Doom 3, but it's official expansion Resurrection of Evil, and the new add-on the Lost Mission. And it also contains the Ultimate Doom and Doom II: Hell on Earth. That alone makes it a great package.

Doom 3 and RoE are just as great as they were before. But, small changes stand out that make this release not as great as the original.
For both D3 and RoE they've adjusted the lighting, making the games brighter. Which, while addressing some complaints, actually takes away from the game's original atmosphere.
Also, they've increased the amount of ammo present in the game world. The original releases already featured way too much ammo. You can have almost 200 shotgun shells by the end of the second level in Doom 3.

That combined with the fact that they've actually reduced the number of enemies in certain encounters, and made a few of the boss fights easier... what was already a pretty easy game has been turned into a cakewalk.

And, the Lost Mission... is awful. A cobbled together campaign made up of bits and pieces of levels from Doom 3 and RoE. It lacks the originality of the original releases, and the feel of polish and fun. A nice addition, but, ultimately... a wasted effort.

The BFG Edition is worth the price to have the entire Doom series in one title, but, if you already own the original releases... you've already got the better versions.

reviewText:
I played Doom 3 when it first came out, way back when...  Graphically it was and is still stunning.  I'm now playing it again, it has a great atmosphere to the game, and actually whilst different styles to the game the Dead Space series I think owes a lot to Doom 3.

Doom 3 is pretty linear in it's game play, the maps lead you through it, you don't have to search endlessly for clues or keycards (which actually I like, as it keeps the action going)...

After a while you do get used to Monster popping up behind you and you quickly learn to be cautious.

Graphically it still looks great despite it being 10 years old and Gameplay wise it keeps you hooked as you roam the corridors wondering where the next Monster will come from.

As for the updates to this edition, there is some negativity about the auto save feature taking you out of the action and to be honest it only really saves at moments where there isn't any action so its not an issue really.  As for the flashlight, I remember playing the original version and actually just found it annoying not being able to turn the flashlight on and shoot at the same time.  Although I think this probably made the game scarier and more disorientating...

As a bonus of course you get Doom and Doom 2 with all the addons which are fun for some nostalgia...

reviewText:
The Doom 3 BFG Edition is the ultimate collection of Doom games. This edition contains Doom 3, the expansion pack Resurrection of Evil, a new expansion called The Lost Mission, Ultimate Doom, Doom 2, and the Doom 2 expansion No Rest For the Living. All of these games have full Steam integration which includes achievements, leaderboards, and multiplayer support (which is dead by now because Doom 3 multiplayer always sucked ♥♥♥♥).

Doom 3 and its expansions are remastered in new HD graphics (I personally don’t see much of a difference).  In fact I’ve noticed that the environments are a lot brighter in Doom 3 which really kills the atmosphere that originally made the game so scary. The textures are noticeably enhanced, but not enough to really warrant paying the retail price.

The Lost Mission is short and uneventful. Essentially just a few more recycled corridors from Doom 3 with nothing new or special. I was expecting a significant expansion like Resurrection of Evil, but it was far from it. I’m happy to be playing the original Doom games though. They run perfect on Windows 7 with great controls and even have achievements. For the first time ever, I’m actually going to finish Doom 1 and 2. It’s fun to play games that defined a genre and the Doom 3 BFG Edition allows just that.

On the whole, it’s a nice edition, but the drawbacks from Doom 3 and the disappointing Lost Mission expansion really let me down. Although they aren’t terrible, they’re still enough to put off fans of the series.

reviewText: I picked this up back in 2004 but never played it beyond a few hours.  I don't remember why.  I must have had a lot of sh*t going on at the time.  I don't even know what I did with the original disc.  So, I picked this up for about $3, I think.  It's a pretty good deal.  I won't get into the older games that come bundled with it.  If you want to get nostalgic, knock-yourself-the-f*ck out.  That lasted about 10 minutes for me and I couldn't stand it.  Who knows if I'll ever revisit it.  But for Doom 3 and everything else, it was a good deal.  And I get it.  It's been changed from the original release.  Who f*cking cares?  Let's be adults or at least pretend to be.  What is it?  The flashlight mechanic?  The original f*cking sucked.  It did.  I remember everyone including myself hating that it was a separate item.  Such a stupid way to force environmental tension that ultimately wears off after a few scripted encounters.  Pure frustration.  So, I'm glad they scrapped it.  Other than that, it still holds up well as a school shooting training simulator.  If the Columbine kids had this, they might have learned enough to kill more.

reviewText:
This version of Doom 3 actually comes with all the original Doom games. So I'll summarize what I felt about all 3 of them.

Doom 1: One of the first shooters ever made. It's actually a lot of fun. The first thing I noticed is that you can't jump or aim vertically. You basically strafe and shoot at enemies and use the shotgun as much as possible. You get a minigun, a rocket launcher, a plasma gun, and of course, the BFG to kill progressively more difficult swarms of enemies. There's not much of a story and the levels are very arcade like in structure. The music fits the era it was made: 8-bit rock music.

Doom 2: Nearly identical to the first Doom but with what seems like more difficult levels. There is a new shotgun which has a higher spread and damage which is great for taking out lots of guys fast, but reloads slower. There are a lot of new enemies that are much harder. You'll face some of the bosses from the first game in almost every level. Doom 2 is like the challenge mode of Doom 1.  There's also more of that 8-bit rock music in every level.

Doom 3: It's making me crazy dizzy. I just set the FPS lower because the 120fps made me so sick. The gameplay is pretty narrow compared to the last two. You're stuck in very narrow corridors similar to Dead Space. I've noticed some similar enemies from the original two games, just now they've been given a more modern look with better graphics and physics. Unfortunetly, even this game is starting to show its age. The textures are basically absent from this game. There's also a more obvious atempt at having a story to this game. I haven't finished the game so I can't say whether or not the story is any good, but it's more interesting now than it was in the past two games. The 8-bit rock music is finally gone. Almost seems like a shame as now the game feels like a typical horror game. It feels like Doom had a baby with James Camerons Alien.""
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I bought the original Doom3 when it was first released. I've played it off and on ever since. Yes, I killed the CyberDemon. Yes, I've played Nightmare. And something like ten years after the original purchase Doom3 can still make me jump. I know where the monsters are. I know where the upgrades are - and still, it can make me jump. That's an awful lot of gameplay for whatever it originally cost me.

I like the BFG edition very much. Yes the gameplay and the graphics and the ambient sounds are all exactly the same. So what?  It's just as terrifying as the original AND you get a double barreled shotgun.
Who could ask for anything more.

reviewText:
If your looking purely for a nostalgic trip then yes buy these.. However if your looking for a deeper nostalgic trip with the letters IDKFA or IDDQD etc.. then just keep on walking. That was first thing I did when I ran Doom 2 for the first time tonight.  Do I need cheats to complete the game? No. Do I want cheats to complete the game 25 years or so after the fact?
Yes

I give this bundle a 5 out of 10 based on value and nostalgic feeling.  The other 5 could be given if they ever patch the no cheats thing or atleast make it a console command.
